member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Annotations.AnnotationBase.Anchor
member.summary: Rotation uses this point as a center point. Tells where to place the anchored point within the control area. For X-dimension, value 0 represents left coordinate of the object and 1 right coordinate. For Y-dimension, value 0 represents top coordinate of the object and 1 bottom coordinate. To define anchor point outside the object area, define values outside range 0...1.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormImg(System.Double)
member.summary: Normalize the absolute imaginary axis value. Means z(d) => r+jx, where ImgR(z(d)) = j(X/Z0).
member.remarks: See http://care.iitd.ac.in/People/Faculty/bspanwar/crl713/smith_chart_basics.pdf page 145.
member.param: Absolute imaginary axis value to normalize to -1..1 range.
member.returns: Normalized imaginary axis value, in range -1..1. Values can be larger, of course, but then they reside outside the unit circle.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormReal(System.Double)
member.summary: Normalize the absolute real axis value. Means z(d) => r+jx, where RealR(z(d)) = R/Z0.

remarks.para: No reason to keep NormReal and NormImg separate, except that not sure if there will be changes later.
See http://care.iitd.ac.in/People/Faculty/bspanwar/crl713/smith_chart_basics.pdf page 145.

member.param: Absolute real axis value to normalize.
member.returns: Normalized real axis value. Normalized to range 0..1. Values outside this range do not fit in the Unit circle.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.AbsImg(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the normalized imaginary value to absolute scale.
member.param: Normed imaginary axis value to convert back to absolute values.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.AbsReal(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the normalized real value to absolute scale.
member.param: >Normed RealValue axis value to convert back to absolute value.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormToAbs(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts normed smith view value to absolute value. Normed value 1 matches the given absolute reference value.
member.param: Smith values imaginary or real part to convert.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.AbsToNorm(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts absolute smith view value to normed value. Normed value 1 is at the center of the chart. Normed value 1 matches the given absolute reference value.
member.param: Smith values imaginary or real part to convert.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormImgToRad(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the Normed imaginary part (normalized reactance) to the grid circle radius in screen space.
member.param: Radius of the unit circle in screen space. Defaults to 1 (radius of 1).
member.returns: Radius of the Imaginary-circle in screen space, if proper UnitRadius is given. Otherwise the Imaginary-circle radius in relative unit circle space.

member.param: Radius of the unit circle in screen space. Defaults to 1 (radius of 1)
member.returns: Radius of the RealValue-circle in screen space, if proper UnitRadius is given. Otherwise the RealValue-circle radius in relative unit circle space.

member.remarks: This is the reverse operation of NormImgToRad method.
member.param: Radius of the Imaginary-circle radius. Value in screen space, if UnitRadius is given, and in UnitCircle space if not.
Radius of the unit circle in screen space. Defaults to 1 (radius of 1)

Radius of the unit circle in screen space. Defaults to 1 (radius of 1)

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormValueToUCValue(Arction.Wpf.Charting.PointSmith)
member.summary: Converts normed smith value value pair to UC coordinates.

remarks.para: The real and imaginary values are normed values of the RealValue and ImgValue axis. Circle radiuses matching those values area calculated, the intersection point of the circles area calculated in normed unit-circle space, and then returned. The other intersection point of the circles is at point 1,0 (in UC space), the Y-component of the RealValue circle center point is 0 (center is at X-Axis), and the X-component of the Imaginary circle is 1. See http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Circle-CircleIntersection.html.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.UCValueToNormedValue(Arction.Wpf.Charting.PointFloat)
member.summary: Convert normed coordinates in unit circle space (Origo at the center of the circle) to matching normed real and imaginary values.
member.returns: PointFloat with Normed RealValue (on X-parameter) and Imaginary (on Y-parameter) components, matching the given coordinates.

member.summary: Determines if the axis shows absolute or normalized values.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.GridDivCount
member.summary: Number of gridlines in the view. Used only if GridType is GridTypeSmith.DivCount
member.remarks:
The value defines number of gridlines to draw in real axis. Imaginary axis will have matching gridlines both on positive and negative side.
One line is always drawn on the center (absolute value of 1) of the grid. With values larger than 1, the lines are divided so that half of them are on left side of the first gridline, and half are on the right side, divided so that the lines are somewhat evenly divided, and placed on positions where their values can be expressed with nice looking values.
It should be noted that because half of the lines are on left side and half on the right and one always on the middle, only changes of 2 are meaningful. For instance, values 4 and 5 produce the same output, 1 in the middle, 2 on left side and 2 on right side.
By setting AutoFormatLabels property to false, SupplyCustomImgString and SupplyCustomRealString events can be used to redefine the label string for the gridlines.
GridReal and GridImg properties GridOptionsSmith.CustomGridLines property can be used To place custom gridlines on the view.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.GridDivSpacing
member.summary: Approximate distance between gridlines in pixels. Used only if GridType is GridTypeSmith.Distance.
member.remarks:
The final distance between gridline positions is not precisely the requested distance, but the requested distance is only taken as starting point, and a value is then search from around that point that can be presented as a nice looking string.
Current reference value has a small effect on the gridline positions, as itll affect on what are the nice values we end up putting the gridlines to.
It should also be noted that each Real gridline has matching Imaginary gridline. At certain parts of the chart the imaginary gridlines are naturally more close to each other than the real gridlines, and thus have more effect on the positioning of the gridlines than the real gridlines.
By setting AutoFormatLabels property to false, SupplyCustomImgString and SupplyCustomRealString events can be used to redefine the label string for the gridlines.
GridReal and GridImg properties GridOptionsSmith.CustomGridLines property can be used To place custom gridlines on the view.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.GridType
member.summary: Defines how the grid is defined. If the value is Distance, GridDivSpacing property will affect the positioning and amount of gridlines. Otherwise GridDivCount will be used in calculations.

member.summary: Fit axis minimum and maxium to show all series values. Note that first argument's value type defines Margin's units (Pixels or Percents).
member.param: Margin to leave between axis minimum or maximum and series values, in percents of minimum...maximum range.
Method sets this true if Y-axis minimum or maximum has changed.
If true, all series points are searched, resulting to better accuracy, but with a cost raised CPU load.
Ignore zeros values from logarithmic axis fitting.
member.remarks: For logarithmic axis, call Fit method with pixel range, for appropriate behavior.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisY.CalculateAxisWidth(Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.AxisLayout,Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.delegateMeasureString,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculates the width of the axis box and the base line division. If Division is 0, all of the width is on right side of the axis line center, if it's 1, all of the width is on left side. Thus width of the left side from the axis line is width * Division and right is width * (1-Division).
member.param: Views Axislayout to be applied with the calculation. Required for the YAxisAutoAlign and YAxisTitleAutoPositioning properties.
Factor of how much of the width is on left side of the axis centerline.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IBGListener
member.summary: Interface for objects that listen for settings updates from ISettings objects. This is part of a demo to test how to separate settings from actual UI objects.
member.remarks:
The IUiSettings object is seen and handled by user, and shareable by multiple different parents (it has no parent bindings, or has many).
It is however bound to multiple of these, and these will in turn contain the cached stuff of the object, and are able to draw themselves and cache the drawdata.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IBGListener.SettingsChanged(Arction.Wpf.Charting.IUiSettings)
member.summary: Method to call from the Settings object (IUiSettings) to notify that the settings has been changed and thus the cached object must become dirty.
member.param: Settings object whose settings has changed.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.BGListenerNode
member.summary: Base implementation of the IBGListerner, with ChartNode. This is part of a demo to test how to separate settings from actual UI objects. The idea is that this can be used as object that holds cached data - DD and settings - of the drawable objects.
member.para: As this is ChartNode, this object is part of the Parent-Child relationship of the chart.

DD usage:
DD's can be set as dirty by SetDirty() or SettingsChanged() methods. These methods do not necessarily dispose or clear the DD, as some operations might be able to reuse the old DD. Setting object dirty will cause the DD's to be updated on next drawing.
Disposing the DD's can be done using FreeDrawData() call. Use this when engine changes or DD's need to be cleared for some other reason.

Drawing:
Object can be drawn by calling the Draw() method. If the object is dirty, the DD is created first. The engine given on call might not be used on DD creation, as some DD creation methods might fetch the engine from the view/chart. The engine parameter might be removed later.

Inheriting: Implement the following methods:
FreeDrawData - Must be implemented. Dispose all DD's and null references. BecameDirty - Called when the object becomes dirty for some reason. If there is no need to react to that, it needs not to be implemented. The Dirtiness is internally stored and Draw() method can check that on calls and generate DD at that time. Draw - Needs to be

Interfaces:
IBGListener: the main interface that defines the listener functionality of this class.
IDDContainer: Allows cleaning and later possibly drawing of the DD's

member.summary: UI side settings object that this uses as source of settings.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.BGListenerNode.Arction#Wpf#Charting#IDDContainer#FreeDrawData
member.summary:
Frees all the DD's. Call when the DD's itself become unusable, like on engine changes etc. Simply dirtying does not have to clear the DD's, as some operations might be able to update the DD's.
Calls the abstract FreeDrawData. Implement it so that it frees all DD's.

member.summary: Frees all the DD's. Call when the DD's itself become unusable, like on engine changes etc. Simply dirtying does not have to clear the DD's, as some operations might be able to update the DD's.
member.remarks: called internally when IDDContainer.FreeDrawData() is called.

remarks.para:

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IUiSettings
member.summary: Interface for UI side Settings objects. Objects inheriting this interface are intended to be the ones that users see and can interact with and think as the actual objects on the chart.
member.remarks: Requires users to implement methods for interacting with IBGListener objects. The idea is that the IBGListener objects call AddBgOject and RemBgObject methods to register / deregister from the UI settings object, and the UI settings object is responsible of notifying the underlying actual object of changes in the settings, so that the object can react to the changes. The interface is implemented at least by the UiSettings class.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IUiSettings.AddBgObject(Arction.Wpf.Charting.IBGListener)
member.summary: Registers the IBGListener to this object. This object is responsible to notify the listener of changes in settings.
member.param: listener to add to the listener list and to be notified of changes.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IUiSettings.RemBgObject(Arction.Wpf.Charting.IBGListener)
member.summary: DeRegisters the IBGListener from this object. The listener is not to be notified of changes any longer.
member.param: listener to remove from the listener list and not to be notified of changes.
member.remarks: True if the removal succeeded. It can fail for instance if it was not on the notification list.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.UiSettings
member.summary: Base class for UI Settings. LC users see these objects as the usable objects handled in the LC. In effect these only store the settings for the actually drawed objects, that inherit IBGListener interface and cache the drawing information. This is part of a test to remove object sharing limitations from LC.

member.summary: Registers the IBGListener to this object and notifies the object of settings changes after this call. Reference to the object is kept as weak reference, so this object will not prevent the listener to be freed.

remarks.para: There is no checks to prevent adding the same object multiple times.

member.param: listener to add to the listener list and to be notified of changes.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.UiSettings.Arction#Wpf#Charting#IUiSettings#RemBgObject(Arction.Wpf.Charting.IBGListener)
member.summary: DeRegisters the IBGListener from this object. The listener is not notified of changes after this.

returns.para: This only removes the first reference to the object, not all of them.

member.param: Listener to remove from the listener list and not to be notified of changes.
member.remarks: True if the removal succeeded. It can fail for instance if it was not on the notification list.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartNode.HandleChartMessage(Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageSeverity,Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Exception,System.Object)
member.summary:
Helper for calling and handling error reports / delivering them to user.
Parameters match the ones on the LC method.
Checks LC reference validity, and tries to notify user through other means if the chart is not available.
member.param: Severity of the message. Select most suitable of the options.
Type of the message. Select most suitable from or create a new one there.

Details of the message. Describe the problem / case for user. Keep in mind that this is the information that we get on bug reports.
If none is defined, a default value is generated based on type and severity.

Stack trace of the problem as string. This can be the current stack trace retrieved through "new StackTrace()", or actual more accurate stack trace, if better one is somehow available (from exception for instance), or we need to remove some parts of the current stack trace.
If the value is not given or it's set to null, current call's stacktrace is used.
If the value is empty (""), it's left as empty.

If set to true, forces the message to be thrown as exception.
Defaults to false.
Possible exception that caused this message. Defaults to null.

Object that is the source of the message.
Defaults to this object.
member.returns: True if message was delivered through chart. False otherwise.

member.summary: Internal (private) method for checking single object reference validity. Intended to be called from method.
member.param: Object reference to check validity of.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartNode.CheckIfInvalidRefAndComplain(System.Object[])
member.summary:
Checks if any of the given objects are null or disposed, and complains to user if they are, and returns true.
Idea of this is to do sanity checks on methods, allowing testing of object references required in the method.
This works identically to , but accepts multiple objects.
Disposed check is done only on ChartNodes
Call this with required refs, and if the return value is false, exit the method or do something, but skip the usage and try to get out of the situation gracefully.
Notifies the user through . Null objects cause message and disposed objects cause type message.
Severity is always .
member.param: Item of which validity is to be checked.
member.returns: True if there was some problem with any of the references.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartNode.CheckIfInvalidRefAndComplain(System.Object)
member.summary:
Checks if the given object is null or disposed, and complains if it's not and returns true.
Idea of this is to do sanity checks on methods, allowing testing of object references required in the method.
Disposed check is done only on ChartNodes
Call this with required refs, and if the return value is false, exit the method or do something, but skip the usage and try to get out of the situation gracefully.
Notifies the user through . Null objects cause message and disposed objects cause type message.
Severity is always .
member.param: Item of which validity is to be checked.
member.returns: True if there was some problem with the reference.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartNode.SetMember``1(``0@,``0,Arction.Wpf.Charting.IChartNodeInt,System.Action)
member.summary: Default implementation of operations to do when setting internal member on setter.

remarks.para: If the old and new value are same, just sets the owner

remarks.para: If the new value is null, creatAction is called. It's supposed to create and set the value. It can be null.

Called if value was null. Expected to set the value and call SetSubnodeOwner etc. Can be null.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartOptions.m_bRaiseEventsAfterDraw
member.summary: Defines if the events raised during rendering should be emitted only at the end of the drawing (frame) or when the changes occur.
member.remarks:
If false, events are raised whenever they occur. Some properties or data may not be valid, because the control draw may not have been finished. That is the case for example when using a series data cursor, and adjusting X or Y axis scale.
If true, events are raised in sequence after the chart drawing has been finished. It ensures all data is valid for external data handling.
Moved from RenderOptionsCommon class to here. Was previously enabled on v6.something.
This only applies to chart's specific events, not events derived from ancestor CustomControl. Error event is not enqueued, but raised whenever it occurs.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartOptions.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Clean up any resources being used.
member.param: true if managed resources should be disposed, otherwise false.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartOptions.FallbackWpfImagePresentation
member.summary:
Forces DX11 rendering on WPF to fallback to the presentation system used with WARP. This property is for testing and debugging purposes only and does not support binding.
This method is intended mainly for debugging purposes. It does not have a Dependency property implementation on bindable charts.
Note that the actual value obeyed by the system might not be reflected by this variable. Please check RenderDeviceInfo.D3DImageUsed returned by GetRenderDeviceInfo() for the actual value.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartOptions.WheelRequiresFocus
member.summary: Defines if the chart reacts to wheel events without focus. This is useful especially on situations when chart is in scrollable control and it's not wished that the chart processes the wheel events.

member.summary: Controls showing debugging information on chart. This is intended only for debugging and special situations.

member.summary: Selects when to show hints about the use of some critical properties.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartOptions.ThrowChartExceptions
member.summary: When set to true, throws a on all events with a level above .

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartOptions.AllowUserInteraction
member.summary: Allow user interaction with interaction device (e.g. mouse). Interaction device hit testing with objects cause CPU overhead when the device is moved. If user device interaction is not absolute necessary directly within chart and if you want to maximize the performance, set this false.
member.remarks: Major part of device hit test overhead is caused by series testing. Series have AllowUserInteraction property too, so set at least that disabled while making real-time monitoring.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartOptions.RaiseEventsAfterDraw
member.summary: Defines if the events raised during rendering should be emitted only at the end of the drawing (frame) or when the changes occur.
member.remarks:
If false, events are raised whenever they occur. Some properties or data may not be valid, because the control draw may not have been finished. That is the case for example when using a series data cursor, and adjusting X or Y-axis scale.
If true, events are raised in sequence after the chart drawing has been finished. It ensures all data is valid for external data handling.
This only applies to chart's specific events, not events derived from ancestor CustomControl. Error event is not enqueued, but raised whenever it occurs.

member.summary: Convert data values to colors, by given palette. Palette is defined by steps, consisting of value and corresponding color. E.g. 0 : Black, 50: Yellow, 100: Red. The output colors are interpolated based on their position between steps. E.g. in this example palette, data value 60 will be almost yellow, but a little bit blending with red.
member.param: Values of palette. Count must be equal to step color count.
Colors of palette. Count must be equal to step value count.
member.remarks: Use fixed interval palette steps only. E.g. 0, 25, 50, 75, 100. NOT like 0, 10, 40, 50, 80, 100.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.CoordinateConverters.SphericalCartesian3D
member.summary: Spherical to 3D cartesian coordinates converter class. Assumes spherical data point to be defined in azimuth / elevation system coordinates. For elevation, the XZ plane is the reference plane. (e.g. equatorial plane). Elevation is angle measured from that plane. To apply values from polar inclination system, use formula Elevation = 90 - Inclination.
member.remarks: Assumes View3D.Dimensions to be equal (cubic).

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.RenderingEngineChangedHandler
member.param: Chart where the device was changed.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.DPIChangedHandler

remarks.para: Microsoft instructs on that all PerMonitor DPI aware applications should listen for WM_DPICHANGED events, and reposition / resize the application window as instructed on the page.
LightningChart does not do this operation by default. This system can be enabled by setting the allowWindowResize parameter to true.

member.param: Chart where the DPI change occurred.

Allow window to be resized after event handler is called.
You should set this to true, if you choose not to react the WM_DPICHANGED event on application side. If set to true, LightningChart will mark the event as handled, and touch window size / position.
The default value is false.

member.name: E:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.OnDPIChanged
member.summary:
Event for DPI change.
Subscribe to this event to receive information of changes on the DPI and to enable automatic LightningChart resizing / repositioning application window on DPI changes. See for more information.

member.summary: Controls if the chart tries to draw anything or not. Mainly intended for stopping rendering during resizes and BeginUpdate and EndUpdate. Skipping of the rendering because of missing engine should be handled separately. Use m_renderingStateLock when using this variable. At least when setting.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.m_renderingStateLock
member.summary: Lock for controlling concurrent access to m_renderingState variable.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.m_spinLockAllowRendering
member.summary: Lock to control concurrent access to DrawChartMain() from same/another thread.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.m_bWaitingForRefresh
member.summary: Defines if the chart is waiting for refresh due to FrameRate limiting.

remarks.para: This is really similar to the m_renderingState, and might be combined to it. It's not done like that yet, because it's enforced by the exportation side extra frame renderings, and it might cause some trouble. Might be good idea to combine later though.
If this is true, DrawChartMain method will refuse to run, as it's expected that the next frame will be rendered only after this is set to false.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.m_bRenderingPending
member.summary: Set this if chart should render after some action, which causes rendering, but is not allowed at the moment. Used for now with mouse move event.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.m_deviceState
member.summary: State of the rendering engine. Note that if the state is DeviceNotCreated it does not necessarily mean that it should be created.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.m_bHeadlessMode
member.summary: Defines if the chart is currently in headless mode or not. This is the current state that has been reacted to. The actual requested state is in RenderingOptions, and this keeps track if we've made required modifications that needs to be made when we enter headless mode. This does not identify the reason, if it's requested headlessness or because of we're in service.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.m_streamOutput

member.name: E:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.RenderingEngineChanged
member.summary:
RendererDevice has changed.
This event is called almost every time the engine changes. Please see remarks for the exceptions

remarks.para: The event is emitted if the rendering device changes, even if it's of the previous type. The event is also emitted the first time the type of the device changes to RendererDeviceType.None, meaning that the user has disabled rendering by setting the engine to none, or the initialization of the engine has failed for some reason. To detect these cases, please follow the ChartError events with type of ErrorType.RenderDeviceCreateFailed.

There as exceptions to cases when this is not called even if the engine changes. These are situations where the engine initialization fails in an unexpected critical way, that might indicate larger problem on chart. At these cases only ChartError event of type ErrorType.RenderDeviceCreateFailed is emitted.

member.name: E:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.ImageDrawnOnChart
member.summary: Event called after image is drawn to chart.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor. Creates new LightningChart object.

remarks.para: LightningChart is highly customizable and fast data visualization tool for just about any need.
Help on how to use LightningChart can be found on Users manual that has been installed with the SDK and on the XML documentation of the library itself.
Examples of how to get things done can be found from demo applications, that contain the source codes of the examples and show how to use LightningChart.

Arction forums at https://lightningchart.com/forum/ contain lots of information on how to use chart. Feel free to send us and other users questions that you cannot find answers to. On support cases you can approach us via e-mail through support@lightningchart.com.
Note that Demo apps have property editor, that can be used to modify the charts on the fly, and thus try out different settings.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.#ctor(Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings)
member.summary:
Creates new LightningChart object.
Takes parameter that can be used in defining certain settings on creation time. Note that some of the settings are dangerous to use, and the constructor itself is intended for advanced use. In normal situation it's better to use the default parameterless constructor.

remarks.para: LightningChart is highly customizable and fast data visualization tool for just about any need.
Help on how to use LightningChart can be found on Users manual that has been installed with the SDK and on the XML documentation of the library itself.
Examples of how to get things done can be found from demo applications, that contain the source codes of the examples and show how to use LightningChart.

Arction forums at https://lightningchart.com/forum/ contain lots of information on how to use chart. Feel free to send us and other users questions that you cannot find answers to. On support cases you can approach us via e-mail through support@lightningchart.com.
Note that Demo apps have property editor, that can be used to modify the charts on the fly, and thus try out different settings.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.HandleWMDPIChangedEvent(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
Event handler for DPI changes. Called when process is per-monitor aware and DPI changes either because the window is moved from screen to other or the user selected new DPI. Stores the new per-monitor DPI (that is not yet used anywhere) and re-positions the window (which is kind of client applications responsibility and thus might be better not to do).
User (client app) can enable the automatic resize by use of OnDPIChanged event.
member.remarks: For more information see WM_DPICHANGED message documentation. https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dn312083%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
member.param: Rect specifying the new suggested position and size of the window.

Setting to true if DPI has changed, and client has not forbidden the resize. In order to set it to be false (original value) on real DPI change, user must have subscribed to the event and set the allowWindowResize to false. By default this parameter should be false when calling this method.

member.summary:
Get effectively used BeginUpdate/EndUpdate counter. Use for debugging, if seems that chart does not render.
The value must be 0 in order for the chart to render. If value is larger, some BeginUpdate call has not been closed by matching EndUpdate call.
This indicates total value. Use GetBeginUpdateCountPublic to see difference of public - user called - BeginUpdate / EndUpdate methods.

member.summary: Updates m_iClientSizeW and m_iClientSizeH variables based on given width / height (in DIPs) and current known DPI coefficients (m_fDPIXCoeff and m_fDPIYCoeff).

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.UpdateDPI
member.summary: Updates internal DPI members from monitor data. Skips update if not required and/or should not be done. After the call m_fDPIXCoeff and m_fDPIYCoeff have valid values.
member.remarks: Delivers the information to the engine. Currently relies on GetDPICoeff and that does not change currently, so for now there is no reason to call this but once, or after engine changes to report it there. Later the use might change however because of the live reaction to DPI / Resolution changes, that we do not yet support properly, as we have no reliable way of ascertaining the new system dpi.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.DrawColoredFill(Arction.RenderingDefinitions.RectangleRD,Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat,System.Double,Arction.Wpf.Charting.Fill,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Draw colored fill.
The fill is drawn at the following position. l = "drawing location", old center, based on given rect. a = is anchor, d = rect diagonal vector, meaning width and height for X and Y-coordinate calculations. ltc = l - a*d (left-top-corner) rtc = ltc + d (right-bottom-corner)
member.param: Coordinates of the unrotated, untranslated rectangle

Anchor. Defines the position of the rotation anchor ad translates the actual rect to a different place. 0.5/0.5 draws the rect as it is defined. 0/0 draws the rect so that top-left corner is at original center.
The idea is that the rects center identifies the "position" of the box.
True if fill is rectangle. False for oval (including circle).

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.DrawColoredFill(Arction.RenderingDefinitions.RectangleRD,System.Double,Arction.Wpf.Charting.Fill,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.param: True if fill is rectangle. False for oval (including circle).

member.summary: Save to file as given size.
member.param: Target file name. You must include file extension (png, bmp, jpg, tif, gif, emf, svg).
Width of required output in pixels (Not in DIPs)
Height of required output in pixels (Not in DIPs)

Allows screen coordinates of certain elements to be scaled by factor of defined size and original size to keep then in place in relation to other chart elements in vector exports. member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.CaptureToByteArray(System.Int32@,System.Int32@,Arction.Wpf.Charting.PixelFormat@)
member.summary:
Get the last frame rendered by the chart as byte array containing just pixel data four bytes per pixel.
To get the image data with headers, like in bpm or png format, use SaveToStream method

remarks.para: Note that it is the last image rendered. If chart has yet not rendered any images with given engine, no proper image can be produced.
To get continuous stream output of the chart, use OutputStream property.

member.returns: chart's last rendered raw image as byte array. Each pixel is represented by 4 bytes in the order defined by the format parameter.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.SetUserInteractiveDevicePosition(Arction.Wpf.Charting.UserInteractiveDeviceEventArgs,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieve position from the given event, store it to internal variables and return to caller. Destination variables are determined from down parameter.
member.param: Event arguments to get the position from.

Determines if the action was a "button down" or something else. Meaning if the event started or is some continuing / ending type.
If it's true, we set and corresponding other variables. It's assumed that the event came due to starting event, like mouse down.
If it's false, we set and corresponding other variables. It's assumed that the event came due to continuing or similar event, like mouse movement, mouse up or wheel scrolling.

remarks.para: We're using the values set through this to track start and end/current coordinates of an action, like dragging.

We're however setting the values no matter what is the current action state or button that. This can lead to unintended situations. e.g. Clicking other mouse buttons after item dragging is initialized and ongoing probably leads to resetting the start coordinates.

member.summary: Handle chart message. Raises event or throws the error as an exception.
member.param: Severity of the message. Select most suitable of the options.
Type of the message. Select most suitable from or create a new one there.
Details of the message. Describe the problem / case for user. Keep in mind that this is the information that we get on bug reports.

Stack trace of the problem as string. This can be the current stack trace retrieved through "new StackTrace()", or actual more accurate stack trace, if better one is somehow available (from exception for instance), or we need to remove some parts of the current stack trace.
If set to true, forces the message to be thrown as exception.
Possible exception that caused this message. Defaults to null.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.RecreateRenderDevice
member.remarks:
Sets m_deviceState to DeviceNotCreated on call. Sets it to DeviceAvailable only if some engine init succeeds. Should not throw exceptions, so check the m_deviceState to see if device creation succeeded. If the init was not successful, m_re is null and a new engine creation was initiated using timer by call to the RecreateRenderDeviceWithTimer, so m_deviceState is actually DeviceNotAvailableWaitingCreationOnTimer if the engine creation fails.
m_listEngineInitResults is reseted on call, and will be filled along engine creation, so it should contain the reasons for the failure.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.InitializeRenderingDevice(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Tries to force the engine initialization in a synchronous fashion. Should have no use in WinForms.
This method allows user to force the rendering device initialization.
Note! Do not force during chart events callbacks, except at AfterRendering event! Causes chart to malfunction, if engine is changed during event handler.
member.remarks:
The engine is re-initialized only if the current engine selection can not result in the currently active device. If it can, the engine is not re-initialized, unless forced.
The method call is synchronous, and the engine is created on call.
member.param: Forces engine reinitialization, even if there should be no reason for it.
member.returns: true if the call resulted in valid engine that is different from the previous one.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChart.OutputStream
member.summary:
Stream to write the rendered frame bitmaps to.
Defaults to null. Set the stream to this property and it will be written with ran data of the images on every frame. See remarks for the format.
This property is intended as the fastest way to capture continuous frames from the chart, especially on Headless mode.

remarks.para: The stream is a raw byte stream, with each pixel described with 4 bytes, one byte per channel. The order of the channels depends on engine and its settings. Use GetLastOutputStreamFormat and GetLastOutputStreamSize methods to find out the format and output size of the last written image. Produced image size should be of the size of the chart, in pixels.
On the contrary to the other properties of the LightningChart, set stream is NOT disposed on chart's dispose.
On the contrary to the other properties, setting this property will not cause new frame to be rendered.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper
member.summary: Static helper class that contains helpers on DPI related issues. Meaning mainly PX to DIP conversions.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.m_pfDpiFactorEffective
member.summary:
Effective System DPI zoom factors.
In WF these are always 1. Use SystemDpiReal or SystemDpiFactorsReal properties instead if you are interested of the real one.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.m_pfDpiFactorReal
member.summary:
Real System DPI zoom factors.
In WF these are always 1. Use SystemDpiReal or SystemDpiFactorsReal properties instead if you are interested of the real one.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.m_bDpiAware
member.summary: Defines if the process is DPI aware.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.m_pfSystemDpiReal
member.summary: Stores the real retrieved system DPI.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.m_pfSystemDpiEffective
member.summary: Stores the set or otherwise modified effective system DPI.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.DpiFactorReal
member.summary: Getter and internal setter of the dpi factor in both direction.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.DpiFactorEffective
member.summary:
Getter and internal setter of the effective dpi factor in both direction.
Setting the value affects the effective system dpi as well.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.SystemDPIEffective
member.summary: Retrieves the effective DPI setting. This is static 96/96 for WinForms. Use SystemDPIReal to get the real system DPI

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.DpiXFactor
member.summary: Effective Zoom factor of the system DPI of the screen width. Factor that describes how many real pixels there are per one DIP in X direction.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.DpiYFactor
member.summary: Effective Zoom factor of the system DPI of the screen height. Factor that describes how many real pixels there are per one DIP in Y direction.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.DpiHelper.DpiAware
member.summary: Defines if the system process is DPI aware or not. Currently there is no way distinguishing between system aware and Per-monitor aware.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType
member.summary: Detailed information about the type of the ChartMessage event

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.MemoryAllocationError
member.summary: Unable to allocate memory for operation. You should run the garbage collection GC.Collect(), and then try the operation again

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.InvalidPropertySetting
member.summary: Invalid property value has been set

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.InvalidSeriesResolverDataWithSeriesEventMarker
member.summary: Series data X coordinate to Y coordinate resolver data has become invalid, because points have been added. Do not use markers as 'TrackSeries' with X axis monitoring monitoring scroll modes. Instead, you should define them as 'AtYValue' and convert them 'TrackSeries' when opening data in review mode, and set the scroll mode to 'None'.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.SeriesIsNotTrackable
member.summary: You are requesting a tracking operation on a series, that is not trackable (does not implement ITrackable)

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.SampleFormatMismatch
member.summary: Samples use different format than you try to use

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.DataPointTypeMismatch
member.summary: Series has been configured to use different data point type than you are trying to use

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.InvalidLogAxisOperation
member.summary: The selected feature can't be used with logarithmic axis

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.ShaderModel3NotSupported
member.summary: Shader model 3 is not supported by the GPU. Some parts of the chart cannot be drawn as intended.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.BeginUpdateEndUpdateCallCountMismatch
member.summary: EndUpdate() is called more often than BeginUpdate().

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.InvalidSaveFileFormat
member.summary: Invalid save file format. E.g. one can't save 3D graph as vector.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.DataBindingCollectionMisuse
member.summary: IsBindableDataUsed is 'true' but non-bindable data collection (e.g. PointLineSeries.Points) is modified instead of bindable data collection (e.g. PointLineSeries.PointsWpf).

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.InvalidAxisIndexForSeries
member.summary: Axis index for axis related item is invalid.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.InvalidSegmentForYAxis
member.summary: Segment or segment index for y-axis is invalid.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.InvalidOwnerViewForItem
member.summary: Item view differs from drawing view.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.LicensingError
member.summary: Problem with licensing. Make sure the license is properly installed.
member.remarks: If you are entitled to use LightningChart, please contact Arction LTD and include the contained detailed error string in the message.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.EventSystemError
member.summary: Problem delivering or calling client side event handlers.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.DrawingOfImageFailed
member.summary: Some exception occurred when graphics object tried to draw image.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.DisposedObjectAction
member.summary: Illegal update action on a disposed object detected.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.ParentSharingError
member.summary: Chart objects parent changed. This could indicate sharing chart's object between multiple parents which is not supported.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.ProblematicCameraOrientation
member.summary:
Requested camera orientation is problematic and might result in different result than expected.
This is similar to but more specific. At this case the user defined camera orientation was somehow problematic on current settings.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.CameraPositioningFailed
member.summary:
Some problem appeared with positioning 3D camera or some other viewpoint / view area.
This is similar to but more general.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.EngineReinitialization
member.summary: Something caused the rendering engine to reinitialize.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.RenderDeviceIsLost
member.summary: Render device is not available anymore.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.RenderInvalidCall
member.summary: Rendering caused invalid call exception. Possibly caused by updating chart from a separate thread without synchronizing it with main program thread. You should use BeginInvoke or Invoke methods for synchronization.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.FrontBufferAvailable
member.summary: Fast WPF presentation element has retrieved the front buffer, and normal presentation of the LC can continue.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.FrontBufferNotAvailable
member.summary: Fast WPF presentation element has lost the front buffer, and LC cannot be presented using it. This can happen for multiple different valid and normal reasons, like hiding of the window, changing to different tab, using through remote desktop, etc, and usually does not require attention. After this the chart will try to use slower fallback presentation method.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.SharpDXBufferCreationError
member.summary: Error on creation of SharpDX Buffer.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.RequirementsNotMet
member.summary: Some of the requirements are not met. Details might present more information.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.ResourceHandlingError
member.summary: Some suspicios or alarming happened with resource management (memory, handles.. ) This might result in rendering device being lost and hopefully reacquired.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.ImagePresentationTimeout
member.summary:
Presentation of image has encountered a timeout problem.
This might be because of a large things to draw, slow system etc, but might indicate a real problem as well.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.RenderingDeviceBlacklisted
member.summary: Use of the detected GPU has been blacklisted for the given purpose.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.LoadingFromFileFailed
member.summary: Load from a file operation failed.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MessageType.CantCompleteOperation
member.summary: Requested operation was not finished. Zooming, drawing or some other operation did not finish as expected. Output might differ from expected. Details will elaborate the issue. .

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HintsVisible
member.summary: Options for defining when to show hints.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HintsVisible.DesignTime
member.summary: Hints are visible only at design time.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.GridTypeSmith
member.summary: Enumeration specifying how the smith grid are to be formed. For more information, see AxisSmith.GridType property.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.GridTypeSmith.Distance
member.summary:
Determine gridline positions so that each line is positioned in a point where the value is nice and event, and distance to other lines is approximately value set in GridDivSpacing.
For more information on actual positioning, see the GridDivSpacing property of AxisSmith.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.GridTypeSmith.DivCount
member.summary: Determine gridline positions so that specific number of gridlines are placed on even distances from the center line, that is always drawn. Number of gridlines can be set using GridDivCount property. See that for more information about positioning of the gridlines.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.GridVisibilityOrder
member.summary: Defines the grids position in relation to other elements in depth direction. In other words, used in defining in which order different objects are drawn.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.GridVisibilityOrder.FrontOfSeries
member.summary: Grid lines in front of series.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.FontsRenderingQuality.High
member.summary: Best anti-aliasing and quality, lowest performance.

remarks.para: On DX9 drawing happens on GDI and is slightly slower and nicer than other levels.
On DX11 drawing is done using ClearType. The final output of the text may vary between users / devices / monitors as windows. Uses user based calibration of the ClearType that affects the rendering.

High quality text setting does not work if the text background is fully transparent all the way through LightningChart, when DX 11 is used. This limitation is part of how the DirectDraw / CleartType works.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LineAntiAliasingType.QLAA
member.remarks: In DX11 somewhat accurately defined outcome that must be met. Different drivers should produce quite similar outcome. Probably slower than ALAA as it relies on multisampling.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LineAntiAliasingType.ALAA
member.remarks: In DX11 a line AA type where driver manufacturer is somewhat free to implement the antialiasing using Alpha Blending in a way they chose as the best. Results vary quite much between different manufacturers. Should be faster than QLAA.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartUpdateTypes
member.summary: Defines how/when chart is updated and new frames are rendered.

remarks.para: Note that size changes are handled separately and they can be changed to be handled in async way separately. Also the MoveToUIhread has similar effect to the Async options.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartUpdateTypes.Sync
member.summary: Chart is updated in sync fashion on property changes. This is the fastest way to get most performance out of the chart and to minimize latency.

remarks.para: Note that with this option it is crucial that property changes / date input is grouped inside / method calls, and that the date input is done as large patches as possible, as otherwise every property change will result in new frame to be rendered, and the calls will happen on sync fashion.
This was the default and only option before LC v 8.1. To keep the old way, use this option.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartUpdateTypes.Async
member.summary: Chart is updated on async fashion. The chart will update as fast as possible after property changes, but the property changes will return as fast as possible, and chart will render new frame at some later point.
member.remarks: This might make it easier to use chart on some cases. Note that this is a new feature and might contain some problems.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartUpdateTypes.LimitedFrameRate
member.summary:
Chart will limit the framerate of the updates to value defined by .
This is similar to the Async option, but keeps prevents new frames to be rendered right after another, thus reducing framerate, but sparing system resources.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.FRLimitTypesInt
member.summary: Defines how to limit the framerate.

remarks.para: Created as part of LC7-808 and LC7-809.
this is for internal usage only. User interface enum is named FrameRateLimitTypes.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.FRLimitTypesInt.Off
member.summary: No RF limitation is to be done.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.FRLimitTypesInt.AsyncTimer
member.summary: Limitation is done through timer in the main thread. Actual fr is bound to be lower than the requested, but probably not by much.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.FRLimitTypesInt.Sync
member.summary: Screen updates are done synchronously. FrameRate limitation is done through waiting, so property setting might be really slow.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ViewAspectRatio.AutoLatitude
member.summary: Calculate aspect ratio based on view center latitude. Applicable only, when map is used. Y-axis center point defines the latitude, proper XY aspect ratio is calculated based in it and X-axis width is modified accordingly. This simulates the projection so that width of objects in the center of the screen are approximately of correct aspect ratio. The estimation can produce bad output on large scale and large center latitude values.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.TextureWrapMode
member.summary: Texture wrapping. Descriptions copied from MSDN: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/bb322814(v=vs.85).aspx

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.TextureWrapMode.Wrap
member.summary: Tiles the texture at every integer junction. For example, for u values between 0 and 3, the texture is repeated three times. No mirroring is performed.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.TextureWrapMode.Mirror
member.summary: Similar to Wrap, except that the texture is flipped at every integer junction. For u values between 0 and 1, for example, the texture is addressed normally; between 1 and 2, the texture is flipped (mirrored); between 2 and 3, the texture is normal again, and so on.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.TextureWrapMode.Clamp
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the texture color at 0.0 or 1.0, respectively.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.TextureWrapMode.Border
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the border color.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.TextureWrapMode.MirrorOnce
member.summary: Similar to Mirror and Clamp. Takes the absolute value of the texture coordinate (thus, mirroring around 0), and then clamps to the maximum value. The most common usage is for volume textures, where support for the full MirrorOnce texture-addressing mode is not necessary, but the data is symmetrical around the one axis.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Cull.None
member.summary: No culling, render all triangles regardless of their normal angle to camera.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.OrientationModes

summary.para: Camera orientation / rotation interpretation types, giving meaning for , and settings and their calculation order, thus affecting camera position and orientation. See remarks for generic information on camera placement and orientation. See different enumeration values and property for more information on available options, their usage and effects.

member.remarks:
Camera positioning / orientation
Camera orientation and position is controlled by multiple different properties.
Defines the location in world coordinates the camera looks at. This location will be at the center of the rendered image.
Distance of the camera from the in world coordinates.
In effect defines how large an area is seen, together with . Modified on zooming operations.
, and
Defines the orientation and thus in effect the position of the camera. Effect of the properties varies based on selected .
Rotation(XYZ) properties define the orientation of the camera. After this the camera is placed so that the is in the center of the view, at away of it.
User device based rotations When user rotates camera using mouse or some other pointer device the orientation changes differently on different orientation modes. Especially horizontal rotation is done around a separate axis, that changes differently on different orientation modes. See different modes for detailed explanation on the rotation differences.
Terminology reference Similar terminology as in Wikipedia is used in this documentation.
Intrinsic Defines orientation as rotations from starting orientation in specific order so that every rotations is done around previously rotated cameras axes, not the world axes.
Extrinsic Defines orientation as rotations from starting orientation in specific order so that every rotations is done on original world axes, not the changed cameras axes.
y-x'-z'' Small letters indicate intrinsic rotations, at the order they are stated.
y' is the rotation around objects Y-axis, done first.
x' is the rotation around objects X-axis, after the first rotation.
z'' is the rotation around objects Z-axis, after the first two rotations.
Z-X-Y Capital letters indicate extrinsic rotations, at the order they are stated. All rotations are done around matching world axes.
Camera up direction The camera and it's position / orientation defines what is seen on the rendered view. Camera position / orientation is mostly defined by and properties, especially if is zero. Camera can however be rotated around it's looking direction, affecting the view. This orientation is defined by camera up vector, a vector that defines what way is up for the cameras view.
There is no accessible property like this, but it's referenced as a concept.
Horizontal rotation axis When camera is rotated by user device, like mouse, new camera orientation is calculated, affecting multiple of the rotation properties. Vertical rotation always affects the camera same way, rotating the view direction around current cameras right direction (X axis).
Horizontal rotation however has its own rotation axis defined. It's not directly readable or settable, but referenced on different parts of documentation and automatically determined based on different orientation settings. Sometimes this is referenced as rotation up direction.
Extra information
For generic information on orientation definition through angles, see Wikipedia article on Euler and Tait-Bryan angles https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_angles.

summary.para: Camera position is defined as X-Y extrinsic rotation and camera up direction by world Z-axis rotation.
This was the only available angle property interpretation used in LC up to version 8.3.
This interpretation has some problematic features and will be deprecated in the future. It's highly suggested to move using interpretation. See Remarks for more information

remarks.para: Defines camera position against property using left hand X-Y extrinsic rotation and rotating camera in-place around world Z-axis.
Camera looking direction is defined by rotating camera first on around world X-axis by degrees, and then around world Y-axis by degrees.
Camera position is calculated based on this orientation, so that the camera is placed so that it looks on the defined .
Camera is then rotated in-place around world Z-axis by degrees.
In effect the camera changes only the cameras up-direction.
Rotations use left-hand rule, meaning that positive angle causes rotation of the camera Counter-Clockwise when looking along rotation axis from negative to positive.

As the camera target is at the looking direction from camera, the camera is at opposite direction from the target. One can think as the angles defining the camera position as well, but the rotation angles are opposite.
X and Y rotations feel quite natural, but with Z-rotation it feels weird, especially from certain angles.
As the rotation is done around world Z-axis, the horizontal camera rotation axis stays on world X-Y plane.
1. The rotation settings does not allow certain orientations.

2. The orientation is not defined if the cameras up direction is parallel to the cameras view direction. At these situations we use a fallback system for calculating the camera orientation. This orientation might differ from the expected one. A ChartMessage warning of type ProblematicCameraOrientation is raised on these situations.
It is preferred to use some other angle interpretation mode to prevent the problems.
When user rotates camera using mouse or some other pointer device, the orientation changes differently on different orientation modes.
Rotation can be separated to two parts, vertical and horizontal, based on the movement of the pointer device.
Vertical rotation is done on seen views horizon - around cameras "right" direction - and affects camera elevation.

Horizontal rotation is done around rotation up direction, that is only affected by set property, that is not really affected by user device based rotation, expect by reversing it when the view crosses the rotation up direction pole.
The rotation up direction is defined as explained before on the Orientation explanation part.
This orientation mode has been available always and the default until v8.4. User device rotation has acted like this from version 7.0 forwards.

member.summary: Calculates the img/real position pair from the current coordinates (m_pointCoords) and sets the internal real/img position pair. member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ExtensionsClass.CalculateGradientColor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate gradient from color to the other with amount given as percents. Each channel is calculated separately and changed with channel difference multiplied by the defined factor. Matches the WinForms color version but implemented differently.
member.remarks: The idea is that this would be faster than the WinForms color version. This is not verified (16/09/26)
member.param: Source color to start from as ARGB integer.
Destination color to move towards as ARGB integer.
Factor to move by, as percents. Negative and values over 100 are valid, though channel values are capped to between [0, 255].

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ExtensionsClass.ColorBytes(System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts color array (int) to ARGB integer. Order of the array matches the int.ToArgb() method. First index (0) is the LSB and last (4) is the MSB.
member.returns: color channels separated into int array

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ExtensionsClass.ToArbg(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Combines int color channels to ARGB integer. Order of the array matches the int.ColorBytes() method. First index (0) is the LSB and last (4) is the MSB.
member.param: Array of ints that defines the color channels

member.summary: Convert given color to currently active platform.

member.summary: Convert given color to currently active platform.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ExtensionsClass.Positive(Arction.RenderingDefinitions.RectangleRD)

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ExtensionsClass.Center(Arction.RenderingDefinitions.RectangleRD)
member.summary:
Center of the rectangle, a vector from the left-top corner to the middle of it. Half of diagonal vector.
Note that the offset of the rectangle is not accounted. To take it into account, use instead.
member.param: Rectangle to calculate the value from.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ExtensionsClass.CenterWithOffset(Arction.RenderingDefinitions.RectangleRD)
member.summary:
Center of the rectangle including the position of the rectangle, a vector from the left-top corner of the reference frame to the center of the rectangle.
Note that the offset / location of the rectangle is accounted. To get just the half of diagonal vector, use instead.
member.param: Rectangle to calculate the value from.
member.returns: Center of the rectangle including the position of the rectangle.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Gdi.RenderDeviceGDIPlus
member.summary: GDI rendering device. Comparable to DX when thinking of RenderingEngines.
member.remarks:
Notes about clipping and stencils:
GDI does not separate clipping and stencils from each other. There is only clipping with different paths.
Therefore there are two Paths for stencil and clipping rectangle. Clip paths are for inclusive and exclusive, which are combined, when stencil is applied.

member.summary:
Sets cliprect, meaning that this starts clipping. When setting clip the old clipping state is closed, a new state is created, and clip rect set, if an empty rect is set, last state is removed clipping is reseted.
For SVG this works a bit differently. On closing the clip state is not reseted.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItem
member.summary:
Interface of objects that can be highlighted.
Allows user to highlight the object and define how the object should be highlighted. The objects also report to users when they are highlighted.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItem.SetHighlight
member.summary:
Highlights the object.
This is a kind of "forced" highlight, and the object might be highlighted even if the highlighting type (defined by Highlight property) is set to None. How the highlighting happens, if any, depends on object. Most objects use the defined type by default, and fall back to Simple highlighting if None is set.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItem.RemoveHighlight
member.remarks: Note that this does not prevent the highlighting caused by mouse hovering.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItem.IsHighlighted
member.summary: returns true if the object is highlighted.

remarks.para: Note that this value reflects the state of the object before it's drawn on screen, so if mouse is moved, this is set, and then a new frame is drawn. Prior version 8.0.1 returned value reflected the currently visible state, meaning that the state changed only after the new frame, and thus right after mouse hovering the state was kind of wrong.

member.returns: True if the object is highlighted.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItem.Highlight
member.remarks: Note that forced highlighting does not necessarily follow this. See SetHighlight for more information.

member.name: E:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItem.HighlightedStateChanged
member.summary: Event telling that highlighted state has changed. Contains information of the new state.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItemInt
member.summary:
Internal interface for the items inheriting IHighlightingItem. Note that there is nothing forcing the inheriting, but both of these should be inherited. We trust it internally.
Allows deliver of the mouse over / off information that allows us to determine if the object is to be highlighted or not.
Also makes it possible for the system to cause the emitting of the notification events.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItemInt.InvokeHighlightedStateChangedEvent(Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightStateSource)
member.returns: True emitting of the event succeeds. If no event listeners is registered, this should return true.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItemInt.SetHover(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
System for notifying the object that the object has been selected through hovering.
Call this every time the object is selected as active object, and with false before new object is selected.
member.param: If true, the object knows it's the currently active object using user interactive device.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.IHighlightingItemInt.SetInternalHL(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Used to HL item internally, through legend box etc.
Similar to the SetHighlighting / RemoveHighlighting, but reports different source to client, and does not change the user set state.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightingItemBase
member.summary: Base class for all LC objects that can be highlighted.

remarks.para: Highlighting style can be controlled through Highlight property.
Reading of the current highlighting state can be read using IsHighlighted() method.
This also makes it possible for the user to manually control forced highlighting of the object.
Presents HighlightedStateChanged event that notifies changes in the objects highlighted state.
Currently changing object visibility and/or highlight mode might not cause event to fire. This is a known problem.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightingItemBase.m_mouseHighlight
member.summary: Defines the type the object is supposed to be highlighted. Set through public interface properties / DP.
member.remarks: By setting this to be property we could react to it and emit event on change. Currently we emit it only on forced change / mouse over changes. Not if visibility or highlight type changes.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightingItemBase.m_bIsDrawnHighlighted
member.summary: Obsolete variable that was used before this system was implemented in V8.0.1. The highlighting was determined on drawtime, and this was set there. Now this is not needed, or used otherwise than to detect the situations where the old draw-time detemination differs from pre-draw determined value. This can be used to find places that has not yet been modified to the new system.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightingItemBase.m_bForceHighlight
member.summary: Defines if the user has requested the item to be highlighted through SetHighlight / RemoveHighlight methods.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightingItemBase.m_bInternalHL
member.summary:
Status of internal highlighting - not through hovering.
For instance legend box hover uses this to hl items.

member.summary: Event telling that highlighted state has changed. Contains information of the new state.

member.summary:
Highlights the object.
This is a kind of "forced" highlight, and the object might be highlighted even if the highlighting type (defined by Highlight property) is set to None. How the highlighting happens, if any, depends on object. Most objects use the defined type by default, and fall back to Simple highlighting if None is set.

member.remarks: Note that this does not prevent the highlighting caused by mouse hovering.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightingItemBase.IsHighlighted
member.summary: returns true if the object is highlighted.

remarks.para: Note that this value reflects the state of the object before it's drawn on screen, so if mouse is moved, this is set, and then a new frame is drawn. Prior version 8.0.1 returned value reflected the currently visible state, meaning that the state changed only after the new frame, and thus right after mouse hovering the state was kind of wrong.
For object to be highlighted, it needs to be visible, and mouse must be in top of it, highlighting must be set manually, or the item must be highlighted by hovering over legend box.

member.returns: True if the object is highlighted.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightingItemBase.Arction#Wpf#Charting#IHighlightingItemInt#InvokeHighlightedStateChangedEvent(Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightStateSource)
member.param: Arguments to use instead of current objects stored MouseEvent arguments. Can be used to speed up speed up the call if the event is already constructed.
member.returns:
Return value of the Charts RaiseEvent method. False if the event could not be emitted, true otherwise.
True emitting of the event succeeds. If no event listeners is registered, this should return true.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightingItemBase.InvokeHighlightedStateChangedEvent(Arction.Wpf.Charting.HighlightStateSource)
member.param: Arguments to use instead of current objects stored MouseEvent arguments. Can be used to speed up speed up the call if the event is already constructed. Note that the object is not updated in any way if given, so it can be used to deliver wrong information.
member.returns:
Return value of the Charts RaiseEvent method. False if the event could not be emitted, true otherwise.
True emitting of the event succeeds. If no event listeners is registered, this should return true.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LineStyle3D.AntiAliasing
member.summary:
Gets and sets anti-aliased line. This is a dependency property. Drawing anti-aliased draws the line with smooth edges, but will increase CPU/GPU overhead.
Note that line width is defined in 3D world coordinates, not in pixels as with 2D line. With DX11, thicker (triangle) lines cannot be rendered without anti-aliasing unless is set to a value lower than 1.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RoutedEventStorage
member.summary: Stores event / handler pairs and later registers them with a given UIElement. The reason for this class is that with XAML we do not have m_chart reference at the time routing events are registered using XAML, and we need the m_chart reference because it's the only UIElement we have and routed events are UIElement functionality.

remarks.para: Created as a separate class so that it's easier to use.
Not usable in WinForms, as it misses the whole concept of WPF routed events.

member.summary:
Constructor.
ProcessKeyParam identifies the instance doing the serialization. Must be unique key for each instance.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Serialization.ProcessedAttribute.UseCount
member.summary: Number that this attribute has been used.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Serialization.SerializationTools
member.summary:
Tools for serialization.
Mainly different helpers for identifying problems on serialization. Nothing really finalized.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Serialization.TreeBinarySerializer
member.summary:
Binary array based serializer for LC objects.
Theoretically supports all kinds of objects, including lists, and serializes their public serializable properties.

remarks.para: Serializes the all public properties it can to a binary format as a tree structure, and sets corresponding properties on deserialize.
Functions even though the original and final type differs. Tries to match the properties based on the name and typename of the objects.
This class is part of the LC's over-the-version designer serialization system.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Serialization.TreeBinarySerializer.ProcessKey
member.summary:
Unique process identifier of the serializer.
As this object might be recreated multiple times, and we might encounter same object multiple times, we need unique identifier that can be used to identify different serialization attempts.
Defaults to 0, but usually set to some random value.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Serialization.TreeBinarySerializer.m_path
member.summary: Default logging path for debugging purposes.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Serialization.TreeBinarySerializer.SerializedThings
member.summary:
Possible types for serialization.
Properties is the working one, fields is in test phase.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Serialization.TreeBinarySerializer.SerializedThings.Fields
member.summary: Fields are serialized. This is not confirmed to work.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Serialization.TreeBinarySerializer.Log(System.String)
member.summary:
Helper logger operation.
Logs given strings to m_path if it's available. Quietly fails if not.
This is slow, as the file is reopened on each request. It's preferable to use Diag.Logger.WriteLine.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Series3D.PointLineSeries3D.m_listPointsSorted
member.summary:
List of sorted points of the series. m_pointsCompact, m_pointsCompactColored or m_points.
Note that this is updated on drawing time, and is of exact size. On use (like mouse hit testing) size of this might be different (in either direction) from m_iActualPointCount, as this is updated on a different time and things can be run in the between. So this is the ordered points of the LAST drawn frame, not the current data.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Series3D.SurfaceGridSeries3D.DrawWireframeThrough
member.summary: If set, draws wireframe through the filled surface, making it always visible from above the surface and below it. Alternatively, you may prefer setting this false and using WireframeOffset to shift the wireframe slightly up or down, making it visible only on the other side of the filled surface.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Series3D.SurfaceSeries3DBase.SetHeightDataFromBitmap(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Drawing.Bitmap,Arction.Wpf.Charting.BitmapAntialiasOptions,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create data based on bitmap file contents. Data array will have dimensions of the bitmap Width X Height. Use options to reduce resolution and smooth it if needed. Height data of is calculated for each pixel from R, G, and B sum. 0 (black) will have the minimum value, and maximum value is obtained from 3*255 (white). If bitmap has alpha value of 0, the data is set to -INF, and the value is not drawn.
member.param: Bitmap resolution decrement and smoothing options. Give null to use pure bitmap data only.
Sets NegativeInfinity when bitmap pixel has alpha = 0.
member.returns: True if data was successfully filled, else false.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.BlockSeriesBase.m_iFirstNewBlockIndex
member.summary:
Index to first block index after dd is composed from previous blocks.
Updated to end index (m_iNextBlockAddIndex) after dd is updated. If data is removed, this is set to begin of remaining data. Also all DD is refreshed in this case. Consider ringbuffer resize, when it must be adjusted, if between 0 and start index of all data.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.BlockSeriesBase.m_iStartBlockIndexForAllData
member.summary: Index to block for start of all used data (e.g. after data is deleted before some x value, this is updated to new start). This is only changed, when dropping old data. Which cause DD refresh.

member.summary: Start index of DrawData vertex buffer, i.e first sample index (or column) to be rendered. Calculated based on sample start value (m_dFirstSampleTimeStamp) and sampling frequency. See CalculateIndexesXFactorAndOffset(..)

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.BlockSeriesBase.m_iPointCountToRender

member.summary: Index to next added block. Tells also last index to render (value - 1). This is always increasing within block Capacity limits. Consider ringbuffer resize, when it must be adjusted, if between 0 and start index of all data.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries
member.summary: Freeform point line series. You can define the line and points style. Add points with AddPoints method.
member.remarks:
The points don't have to be in successive order by X value. If they are used in successive order in your application, you should use PointLineSeries or SampleDataSeries instead for optimal performance. Freeform point line series causes significantly higher CPU/GPU load than other line series types, when the series point count is high.
Note that the first array is not necessarily the first point of the series, as the Points array is a circular buffer.
