member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.SolveYCoordsAtXCoord(System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Find all instances of FreeformPointLineSeries intersection with vertical line going through the given X-coordinate. The intersection point is described by segment of line (pair of LineSeries points) it is found. Each intersection point is returned as structure, and method returns the list of those structures.
Note that you might be interested in using for some of the use cases.
X-coordinate in pixels or DIP. Use DIP instead of pixels as parameters. Iterable list of solve results.

item.description:
Minimum index among the points related to hit.
Minimum index can be used for getting actual index of point related to hit from the original points array. This might be useful in scenarios, where you want to first solve point from coordinate by using this method and then get the actual value of that point.
Nearest X-coordinate of actual data point among the points related to hit, calculated from given input X-coordinate.
Number of points directly related to hit.
Defines if points/hits were found for given X-coordinate or not.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.SolveYValuesAtXValue(System.Double)
member.summary:
Find all instances of FreeformPointLineSeries intersection with vertical line going through the given X-value. The intersection point is described by segment of line (pair of LineSeries points) it is found. Each intersection point is returned as structure, and method returns the list of those structures.
Note that you might be interested in using for some of the use cases.
X-value. Iterable list of solve results.

item.description: Nearest data point index among points, calculated from given X-value.
Nearest X-value of actual data point among the points related to hit, calculated from given X-value.
Defines if points/hits were found for given X-value or not.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.LinePointsToCoords(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32[]@,System.Boolean,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32[]}@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts line series points to equivalent coordinates. May drop overlapping subsequent points.
member.param: Sweep page index. 0 for first, 1 for second
First value to draw. When drawing first sweep page, it's stupid to draw points overlapping the second page. If unsure, use xAxisMin.
Number of points to rewind before starting to seek start.
Must give data point indices out if true
Data point indices that were included in the coordinates array. One array per Databreaking (e.g. NaN separated) block.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.PointsToCoords(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32[]@)
member.summary: Converts line series points to equivalent coordinates. May convert points hitting same x coordinate into a vertical column.
member.param: Sweep page index. 0 for first, 1 for second
First value to draw. When drawing first sweep page, it's stupid to draw points overlapping the second page. If unsure, use xAxisMin.
Start reading from this many points before x axis minimum to make first point visible.

member.summary: Converts line series points to equivalent coordinates. May convert points hitting same x coordinate into a vertical column.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.PointCountLimit
member.summary: Point count limit. If you add points more than limited count, first points are automatically removed. The limiter only applies if PointCountLimitEnabled is true. If PointCountLimitEnabled is true, the array of corresponding size will be create in memory.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.OldestPointIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of oldest point in Points array. When PointCountLimitEnabled is true, the Points array is used as an circular point buffer. This is 0 always when PointCountLimitEnabled is false. To read Points, when OldestPointIndex is 0: Read from index 0 till PointCount-1. To read Points, when OldestPointIndex is > 0: First read from OldestPointIndex till PointCountLimit-1. Then read from index 0 till OldestPointIndex-1.

member.summary: Tells how often the draw data is cleared when using X-axis scroll mode. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstructs the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstructs the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.IntensitySeriesBase.SetHeightDataFromBitmap(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Drawing.Bitmap,Arction.Wpf.Charting.BitmapAntialiasOptions)
member.summary: Create data based on bitmap file contents. Data array will have dimensions of the bitmap Width X Height. Use options to reduce resolution and smooth it if needed. Height data of is calculated for each pixel from R, G, and B sum. 0 (black) will have the minimum value, and maximum value is obtained from 3*255 (white). If bitmap has alpha value of 0, the data is set to -INF, and the value is not drawn.
member.param: Bitmap resolution decrement and smoothing options. Give null to use pure bitmap data only.
member.returns: True if data was successfully filled, else false.

member.param: Data. The alignment must be M x N, all rows must be of equal length.
Jagged array order dimensions order. Is first array dimension columns and second dimension rows, or vice versa.
member.remarks: Only works when Fill = FromSurfacePoints.
If SetValuesData method is used too, the data array dimensions and order must be same than with SetColors.

member.summary: Interface flag for series that can be - Shifted in real-time, by using incremental rendering data construction, with XAxis.ScrollMode == Scrolling/Sweeping/Stepping, and setting XAxis.ScrollPosition periodically. member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.PointLineSeries.ScrollModePointsKeepLevel
member.summary: Tells how often the draw data is cleared when using X-axis scroll mode. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstructs the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstructs the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. Reserves some extra memory.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.SampleDataSeries.ScrollModePointsKeepLevel
member.summary: Tells how often the draw data is cleared when using X axis scroll mode. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstructs the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstructs the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. Reserves some extra memory.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.StockSeries.CombineCoordinates(System.Collections.Generic.List{Arction.RenderingDefinitions.StockSeriesPointCoordinates[]},System.Single)
member.summary:
Combines two first arrays of the input list, shifting the X coordinates of the first array by fScrollModeOldShiftX using ShiftXData method.
If input list listArray has one item, it is returned _unshifted_. Otherwise ShiftXDate method is used to shift the first array and the second array is copied to the output array as it is. Other arrays of the input list are ignored.
The input list is cleared.
member.param: List of max 2 arrays, that are combined so that first one is shifted by the given amount. The input list is cleared.
Amount to shift (add to x values) of the first array of the input list.
member.returns: Null for null input and if more than one arrays on list but no points. Original first array if list count is one Otherwise the output array contains first array shifted with fScrollModeOldShiftX and copy of the second array.

member.summary: Tells how often the draw data is cleared when using X-axis scroll mode. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstructs the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstructs the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. Reserves some extra memory.

member.summary: True if optimal pure device mode is supported.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.FastVertexFormat
member.summary: True if your graphics adapter supports fast vertex format. Fast vertices are not available for old graphics adapters. If false, the rendering performance is not optimal, since slower vertex formats must be used. Getting a new graphics adapter is strongly recommended, ensure it is at least DirectX 10 level, for best performance.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.HardwareVertexProcessing
member.summary: True if your graphics adapter supports vertex processing in hardware (GPU). If false, the vertex calculation has to be done in software (computer CPU), and the performance is not optimal.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.ShaderModel3
member.summary: True if shader model 3 is supported. Both vertex and pixel shaders are format 3 or greater.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.IndexBuffers32Bit
member.summary: True if 32-bit index buffers are supported. If only 16-index buffers are supported, returns false. In this case the 3D surfaces may be limited into smaller sizes.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.TexturesSizesNonPowerOf2
member.summary: Limited support for textures which size is not power of two.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.D2Dv11Supported
member.summary: True if D2D v1.1 is supported, false if not. The v1.1 is required for HW text rendering on DX11. On DX9 this is always false.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.DpiAware
member.summary: True if software is DPI aware.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.Memory
member.summary: Memory on the graphics card (if information is available).

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.AllGPUs
member.summary: All GPUs installed in the system.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings
member.summary:
Rendering settings, that can be given as chart constructor parameter to set the creation time parameters. Speeds up creating of the chart, if non-default values are given, preventing the chart rendering engine to be re-created several times.
Note that the values are only read once after the chart is created, and changing them later has no effect. To change values after chart has been created, use Charts ChartRenderOptions property on WPF, or RenderOptions property on WinForms, both of type
This object can be shared between multiple charts.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.AntiAliasLevel
member.summary: Anti-aliasing factor. 1 = no anti-aliasing. The larger the value, the smoother the image will be, but at steep cost of performance on some display adapters. Only objects having AntiAlias property will be anti-aliased, if it's set to 'Normal'.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.WaitforVSync
member.summary: Wait for next refresh, V-Sync. If the computer is fast enough, disabling this can give higher refresh rate than the screen refresh rate is. By disabling this, rendering does not wait next screen refresh turn. Enabling this may improve performance especially in slow computers.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.D2DEnabled
member.summary: Temporary debug setting for disabling D2D system and text rendering on DX11.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.ChartMessageDelegate
member.summary:
Delegate to register to the ChartMessage event. Initialized this way the chart error event is launched even before the object has been fully constructed.
Intended primarily as debug measure for cases when LC crashes on constructor and we need more information on why it happens.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.DeviceType
member.summary: Default rendering device engine to use. Defaults to Auto.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.HeadlessMode
member.summary: Identifies that we do not actually have a graphical interface. This is true for instance for services or console applications. This can also be used if the chart is intended to run on background without an actual interface.

member.summary: Constructor for Form designer list editor.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement
member.summary:
The base class for SVG elements. It represents some part of an SVG document, either an element (rect, circle etc) or a text item. Duties include:
Maintains a list of child elements and a list of attributes.
Writes itself and its children to an Xml document.
Reads itself and its children from an Xml document.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.ReadXmlElement(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Given a document and a current node, read this element from the node.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.WriteXmlElements(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Given an XML document and a parent node, write out this node and its descendants as XmlElements.
member.param: A node, or null if this element is to be the root element

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.ToString
member.summary: A simple ToString() for use in debugging.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.WriteSVGString(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get a string that contains a complete SVG document. XML version, DOCTYPE etc are included.
member.param: Should usually be set true. Causes the XML output to be optimized so that long attributes like styles and transformations are represented with entities.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.AddChild(Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement)
member.summary: Adds a child, and sets the child's parent to this element.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.AddChildren(Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement[])
member.summary: Adds a variable number of children

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.Children
member.summary: An ArrayList containing this element's children

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.Attributes
member.summary: A hashtable containing this element's attributes. Keys are strings but values can be any type; they will only be reduced to strings when this element needs to convert itself to XML.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.Parent
member.summary: The element whose child this element is; can be null, because SvgElements may only be inserted into a full SVG tree long after they are created.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.Item(System.String)
member.summary: A quick way to get and set attributes.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.Name
member.summary: The name of the XML element that this SVG element represents.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory
member.summary: Static methods to produce/write/copy Svg documents reside in this class.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.LoadFromXML(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Given an xml document and (optionally) a particular element to start from, read the xml nodes and construct a tree of objects. Xml tags that do not correspond to a particular class will be represented by an . This means that literally any XML input can be read in and written out, even if it has nothing to do with Svg. More usefully, it means that new and unsupported tags and attributes will be represented in the SvgElement tree and written out correctly even if SvgNet does not understand them.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.CompressXML(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary:
Helper function to compress long xml attributes into entities.
This would work on any XML, it is not SVG specific, so it should eventually be in some 'xml tools' class.
member.returns: A string of entities which can be inserted into the DOCTYPE when the document is written.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.RecCompXML(System.Collections.Hashtable,System.Collections.Hashtable,System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement,System.Int32@)
member.param: Map of attribute to number of occurrences -- could be used to improve algorithm
Map of attribute to entity name
Number that is incremented to provide new entity names

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.CloneElement(Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement)
member.summary: Create a complete deep copy of the given tree of SvgElement objects. A new set of elements is created, and if the attributes are cloneable they are deep-copied too. Since strings and all SvgType classes are cloneable, the new tree is independant of the old.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgTitleElement
member.summary: Represents an SVG desc element. As with the SvgTextElement, the payload is in the enclosed text rather than in attributes and subelements, so we need to specially add text when serializing.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgDescElement
member.summary: Represents an SVG desc element. As with the SvgTextElement, the payload is in the enclosed text rather than in attributes and subelements, so we need to specially add text when serializing.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgTextElement
member.summary: Represents a text element. The SVG text element is unusual in that it expects actual XML text nodes below it, rather than consisting only of attributes and child elements (other elements like this are title, desc, and tspan). SvgTextElement therefore has to be serialized to XML slightly differently.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgTspanElement
member.summary: Represents a tspan element. The tspan element is unique in that it expects actual XML text nodes below it, rather than consisting only of attributes and child elements. SvgTextElement therefore has to be serialized to XML slightly differently.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgException
member.summary: A general-purpose exception for problems that occur in SvgNet.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgException.Ctx
member.summary: A string intended to supply context information.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.IGraphics
member.summary:
An interface that contains exactly the same methods as the GDI+ Graphics object. If your drawing routines draw to an IGraphics interface, then you can supply either a GdiGraphics object to render to the screen, or an object to render to an SVG file.
It's a pity that Graphics is a sealed class. Otherwise there'd be no need to have this interface or the class; we could simply derive a class from Graphics to do SVG output.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.GdiGraphics
member.summary: An IGraphics implementation that simply passes every call through to a GDI+ Graphics object.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGdiNotImpl
member.summary: Exception thrown when a GDI+ operation is attempted on an IGraphics implementor that does not support the operation. For instance, SvgGraphics does not support any of the MeasureString methods.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics
member.summary:
This is an IGraphics implementor that builds up an SVG scene. Use it like a regular Graphics object, and call WriteXMLString to output SVG. In this way, whatever you would normally draw becomes available as an SVG document.
SvgGraphics has to do quite a lot of work to convert GDI instructions to SVG equivalents. Some things are approximated and slight differences will be noticed. Also, in several places GDI+ does not do what it is supposed to (e.g. arcs of non-circular ellipses, truncating bitmaps). In these cases SvgGraphics does do the right thing, so the result will be different.
Some GDI instructions such as MeasureString are meaningless in SVG, usually because there is no physical display device to refer to. When such a method is called an exception is thrown.
Many parameters used by GDI have no SVG equivalent -- for instance, GDI allows some fine control over how font hints are used. This detailed information is thrown away.
Some aspects of GDI that can be implemented in SVG are not. The most important omission is that only solid brushes are supported.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.MatrixStack
member.summary:
This class is needed because GDI+ does not maintain a proper scene graph; rather it maintains a single transformation matrix which is applied to each new object. The matrix is saved and reloaded when 'begincontainer' and 'endcontainer' are called. SvgGraphics has to emulate this behaviour.
This matrix stack caches it's 'result' (ie. the current transformation, the product of all matrices). The result is recalculated when necessary.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.WriteSVGString
member.summary: Get a string containing an SVG document. The very heart of SvgGdi. It calls WriteSVGString on the at the root of this SvgGraphics and returns the resulting string.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawString(System.String,System.Drawing.Font,System.Drawing.Brush,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary:
Implemented.
In general, DrawString functions work, but it is impossible to guarantee that an SVG renderer will have a certain font and draw it in the same way as GDI+.
SVG does not do word wrapping and SvgGdi does not emulate it yet (although clipping is working). The plan is to wait till SVG 1.2 becomes available, since 1.2 contains text wrapping/flowing attributes.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawIcon(System.Drawing.Icon,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Implemented. The DrawIcon group of functions emulate drawing a bitmap by creating many SVG rect elements. This is quite effective but can lead to a very big SVG file. Alpha and stretching are handled correctly. No antialiasing is done.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawImage(System.Drawing.Image,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary:
Implemented. The DrawImage group of functions emulate drawing a bitmap by creating many SVG rect elements. This is quite effective but can lead to a very big SVG file. Alpha and stretching are handled correctly. No antialiasing is done.
The GDI+ documentation suggests that the 'Unscaled' functions should truncate the image. GDI+ does not actually do this, but SvgGraphics does.

member.summary: Implemented. There seems to be a GDI bug in that the image is *not* clipped to the rectangle. We do clip it.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.HandleBrush(System.Drawing.Brush)
member.summary:
When a GDI instruction with a brush parameter is called, there can be a lot we have to do to emulate the brush. The aim is to return a style that represents the brush.
Solid brush is very easy.
Linear grad brush: we ignore the blend curve and the transformation (and therefore the rotation parameter if any) Hatch brush:
Other types of brushes are too hard to emulate and are rendered pink.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgAngle
member.summary: An angle, as found here and there throughout the SVG spec

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgColor
member.summary: A color, as found in CSS2 and used in SVG. As well as a GDI Color object, SvgColor stores the string it was initialized from, so that when a color specified as 'black' is written out, it will be written 'black' rather than '#000000'

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgColor.FromString(System.String)

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgColor.ToString

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.PathSeg
member.summary: A segment in an Svg path. This is not a real SVG type; it is not in the SVG spec. It is provided for making paths easier to specify and parse.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPath

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPath.FromString(System.String)

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPoints

member.summary: A number list, as used in the SVG spec for e.g. the value of a viewBox attribute. Basically a list of numbers in any format separated by whitespace and commas.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgUriReference
member.summary: Represents a URI reference within a style. Local uri references are generally strings of the form url(#elementID). This class should not be confused with which represents the xlink:* properties of, for example, an a element.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgXRef
member.summary: Represents a URI reference. Unlike most svg types, uri references are represented by more than one attribute of an element. This means special measures are required to get and set uri references.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.AngleDiffDeg(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
Solve smallest absolute difference between two angles in degrees. This takes in account the periodic nature of the values, meaning that full circles do not affect the difference.
Useful in comparing the difference of angles, e.g. on testing if angles are the same.
Note that the type of angle unit affects the result. Use for radians.

remarks.para: 350 to 10 = 20 degrees
10 to 350 = 20 degrees
-360 to 350 = 10 degrees

member.param: One of the angles to calculate the difference between in degrees. Order of parameter does not matter.
One of the angles to calculate the difference between in degrees. Order of parameter does not matter.
member.returns: Difference of provided angles in degrees. Always positive.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.AngleDiffRad(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
Solve smallest absolute difference between two angles in radians. This takes in account the periodic nature of the values, meaning that full circles do not affect the difference.
Useful in comparing the difference of angles, e.g. on testing if angles are the same.
Note that the type of angle unit affects the result. Use for degrees and examples.
member.param: One of the angles to calculate the difference between in radians. Order of parameter does not matter.
One of the angles to calculate the difference between in radians. Order of parameter does not matter.
member.returns: Difference of provided angles in radians. Always positive.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.AngleDiff(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
Solve smallest absolute difference between two angles with the given size of full circle. This takes in account the periodic nature of the values, meaning that full circles do not affect the difference.
This is the internal version of the method, working with any degree type, used by the public versions.
Useful in comparing the difference of angles, e.g. on testing if angles are the same.
member.param: Amount of full circle, in selected units. Required in calculations to get the difference correct between different rotations.
One of the angles to calculate the difference between. Order of parameter does not matter.
One of the angles to calculate the difference between. Order of parameter does not matter.
member.returns: Difference of provided angles in input angle type. Always positive.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.LinearFitSolveFactors(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculate linear fit from given points. Makes best fit with Least Square regression method. A line equation is y = k*x + b, that is, y = gradient * x + coefficient
member.param: Coefficient, Y value of intersection where X = 0
member.remarks: X values array length must be equal to Y values array length

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.LinearRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Calculate linear line fit for given points
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.PolynomialRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate polymial line fit. Calculates polynomial factors, and uses these factors to solve Y values based on given X value array.
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
Order of polynomial. Usually more than 3 shouldn't be used
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.PolynomialRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Calculate polymial line fit. Calculates polynomial factors, and uses these factors to solve Y values based on given X value array.
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
Order of polynomial. Usually more than 3 shouldn't be used
Polynomial result factors, length = order+1. For example, when having order 2, you can plot line with equation: Y = factors[0] + factors[1]*X + factors[2]*X^2
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.GetMaxDistancesToVectors(SharpDX.Vector3[],System.Collections.Generic.IList{SharpDX.Vector3})
member.summary:
Finds maximum distances of points in the direction of given vectors.
In more detail, the distance calculated and compared is the distance of the point from the origo in the direction of the given vectors.
Idea is to provide list of vectors (currently 4) normal to view area edges and call this to get the maximum distances along the vectors, to find out which items per vector define the zoomed in camera position.
Used in 3D ZoomToFit operations.
Currently supports only vector lists of 4 items.
member.param: List of directions to calculate the directions at. Currently vector count must be 4.
member.returns: Array of distances along the vectors. Currently 4 values.

remarks.para: Will crash if called with other than 4 vectors.

member.summary: Checks if the vectors are parallel.

remarks.para: Normalized versions of vectors are formed if the inputs are not normalized already. In effect, the method is faster to run if the vectors are normalized.

member.param: One of the vectors to inspect. Prefers normalized version.
One of the vectors to inspect. Prefers normalized version.
member.returns: true if the vectors are parallel.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.AngleDegInFirstFullCircle(System.Double)
member.summary:
Retrieve the input angle value as positive angle of the first full rotation in degrees.
Note that the range contains 0, but not the "full angle" of 360 degrees.
member.param: Angle to find the equivalent angle in degrees.
member.returns: Angle matching the input in first full positive round as degrees.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.AngleRadInFirstFullCircle(System.Double)
member.summary:
Retrieve the input angle value as positive angle of the first full rotation in radians.
Note that the range contains 0, but not the "full angle" of PI radians.
member.param: Angle to find the equivalent angle in radians.
member.returns: Angle matching the input in first full positive round as radians.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.AngleInFirstFullCircle(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
Retrieve the input angle value as positive angle of the first full rotation.
Note that the range contains 0, but not the "full angle", defined as range parameter.
member.param:
Amount of full circle range. 2PI for rads, 360 for degrees, 1 for rounds. Required for computations. Not included in the output.
Behavior is undefined for negative values.
Angle to find the equivalent angle.
member.returns: Angle matching the input in first full positive round.

member.summary: Solves nearest world unit vector to the given vector.

member.returns: Closest unit vector for given vector.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.AnglesToCameraVectors(Arction.Wpf.Charting.OrientationModes,System.Double[],SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Vector3@)
member.summary: Converts given camera orientation angles to camera orientation vectors, obeying given value.

remarks.para: The method is part of the camera rotation / orientation system.
Handles at least some extra cases if DEBUG_EXTRA_ANGLE_TYPES define is set.

member.param: Interpretation of the rotationRadsXYZ parameter values.
Double array of the orientation angles to use as input. These should be the values of , and angles, in that order. The method will throw an exception if there is not 3 values in the array.

Calculated camera view direction (from camera to target) matching the given input parameters.
Multiply by -camera distance to get the camera position in relation to target and add camera target vector to get the camera position in the world.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.CameraVectorsToAngles(Arction.Wpf.Charting.OrientationModes,SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3)
member.summary:
Converts given camera orientation vectors (up and view direction) to camera orientation angles, obeying given orientation mode.
The input parameters match those of the output parameters of method.

remarks.para: The method is part of the camera rotation / orientation system.

member.param: Interpretation of the camera orientation angles, affecting the way the return value is formed.

Camera view direction (from camera to target)
Subtract camera target vector from absolute camera position in the world to get the view direction.
Direction of the cameras Up direction
member.returns: Double array of the orientation angles matching the given orientation vectors. The array contains camera orientation angles in order XYZ. This is also the format that is expected on method as input.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.GrowAreaByAspectRatio(Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat@,System.Single)
member.summary:
Increase given area defined as based on the given aspect ratio (width / height).
This is used especially on camera control and drawing side, where the aspect ratio defines which size of the area grows, as the area must maintain the minimum size of the smaller dimension.
The code was used in multiple places so it was moved to single place to keep it uniform.
member.param: Aspect ratio to use in modifying the referenced area.

member.returns: True if any of the fields of the given matrix is NaN.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.AntiAliasLevel
member.summary:
Anti-aliasing factor. 0 and 1 = No anti-aliasing. The larger the value, the smoother the image will be, but at steep cost of performance on some display adapters. Only objects having will be anti-aliased.
Note that with DX11 thicker (triangle) lines cannot be rendered without anti-aliasing unless this property's value is set to be lower than 1.
member.remarks: Note that the value will be limited to a highest value the active engine supports and updated on engine initialization.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineAAType2D
member.summary:
Anti-aliasing type of single pixel width anti-aliased lines. Applicable only on DX11 and when AntiAliasLevel is above 1. Lines thicker than 1 pixel are rendered using triangles, and use triangle drawing AA system. ALAA option produces generally best looking line and is faster than QLAA. There is some problems with ALAA with Warp though.
Note that on DX11, the usage of alpha-line anti-aliasing can be also controlled through

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineAAType3D
member.summary:
Anti-aliasing type of single pixel width anti-aliased lines. Applicable only on DX11 and when AntiAliasLevel is above 1. Lines thicker than 1 pixel are rendered using triangles, and use triangle drawing AA system. ALAA option produces generally best looking line and is faster than QLAA. There is some problems with ALAA with Warp though.
Note that on DX11, the usage of quadrilateral-line anti-aliasing can be also controlled through

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineOffset
member.summary: Debug Line offset of the DX11 line drawing. LightningChart internally uses coordinate system where the coordinate points to the center of the pixel. Meaning that screen coordinate (0,0) is at the center of the top-left pixel. In DX9 this is the same. In DX11 the point (0,0) is at the top-left corner of the top-left pixel, and the center of the pixel is at point (0.5, 0.5). The points are moved by this offset in DX11 engine, so that the chart can use the same coordinate system with all engines. The default value of (0.5, 0.5) is the "correct" one, but it can be modified by this property.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.WaitForVSync
member.summary: Wait for next refresh, V-Sync. If the computer is fast enough, disabling this can give higher refresh rate than the screen refresh rate is. By disabling this, rendering does not wait next screen refresh turn.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.InvokeRenderingInUIThread
member.summary: Use thread safe updates to force the control draw itself though Invoke. Enabling this may cause slower updates, and should not be used in applications running without auxiliary threads updating the chart data or properties. Alternatively, you can use Invoke method of your parent form or control. You should always update the chart data from by Invoking in application side.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UpdateOnResize
member.summary: Update chart always when resizing control.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UpdateOnResizeTimeInterval
member.summary: Update chart after this interval (ms) after resizing ends, if UpdateAlwaysOnResize is false.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.RemoteDesktopVendorId
member.remarks: If remote desktop does not seem to work, set this value to GPU ID.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.HeadlessMode
member.summary:
Defines if the LightningChart expects to have a graphical interface or not. This allows the LC to be used in the background, without connections to interface.
This has effect on multiple different things. For instance device type selection will cause the engine to change instantly on selection, not when LC is connected to visual tree.
member.remarks:
Note that this represents the user selection for the headlessness. Running in service will cause the headlessness to be forced on.
Also note that only DX11 supports headless mode. DX9 will not work in headless mode.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.DeviceType
member.summary:
Rendering device type to use, or selection logic for the engine to be used.
Note that reading this value does not provide information of the current device, just the requested one. More information on remarks.

remarks.para: See the RenderDeviceType enum value for more information on possible selections and their meaning.

The property does not provide information of the currently active device type, just the requested one. Use RenderDeviceInfo.RendererDeviceType value from GetRenderingDeviceInfo() method, or follow RenderingEngineChanged event, to get the currently active device.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.ForceDeviceCreateOnResize
member.summary: Force device create on control resize. Some virtual machine environment require this to be set to true.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.GPUPreference
member.summary: Gets or sets GPU preference setting. This is a dependency property.

remarks.para: Defines which GPU / Graphics adapter of the computer is used. See enumeration for more information.
Note that this property has effect only on DX11, as on DX9 the system handles selection of the used GPU. At DX9 the selection is based on system settings and on screen the application launches on.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.FrameRateLimit
member.summary: Maximum frames to present in second.

remarks.para: This system can be used to limit the FPS of the chart to certain amount of frames per second. The limitation is not exact. Limiting will reserve CPU and GPU usage for other purposes. If no limitation is used, chart will try to update itself synchronously on every change that requires update, like on property changes, data insertion etc.
Note that BeginUpdate and EndUpdate methods should be used when updating properties to prevent unnecessary updates.
This variable controls only the time between frames. The system must be enabled separately through UpdateType property of the ChartOptions.
Value must be larger than 0. The maximum time between frames is one second, so in effect the FPS can not be limited below one FPS.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UpdateType
member.summary: Defines how / when chart is updated and new frames are rendered.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D
member.summary:
Camera in 3D view.
Defines how and from what direction the world is seen from.
member.remarks:
Projection. Camera supports three different projection types, as defined by property.
Projection defines how the elements on 3D world are shown on the screen, i.e. how are they projected onto the 2D surface.
The projection is the default, and resembles "real world" as closely as possible.
Other options are two versions of orthographic (Wikipedia link) projections, with slight difference on zooming behavior.
New orthographic projection and property was introduced in v8.4. and used as default orthographic projection hence. Before that the projection selection was done by now obsolete property.
For more information on possible values and their documentation, see enumeration.
Location and orientation.
The camera look on to the form away. Camera location and orientation in is defined in relation to the by , and properties. Meaning of these properties is defined by property. The possible values can be limited by the use of and for X-axis rotation, and the respective properties for Y- and Z-axis.
Orientation system has been changed in v8.4. when the new orientation mode was introduced and set as default. To use the old way, set the orientation mode to .
Note that the selected orientation mode affects mouse rotation behavior as well.
For more information on the effects and differences of the different modes, see documentation.
Field of view. Camera controls the field of view as well. The feature is controlled through property.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.m_fBadLenLimit
member.summary:
Limit for detecting misformed view matrix.
Used in method.

remarks.para: An internal static value to prevent magic numbers.

Defines the minimum length^2 of the matrix up and right vectors. Idea is that if either of the lengths is less than that, when formed from normalized vectors, something has gone wrong in calculations, as the lengths (non-squared) should be approximately 1.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.m_viewMtx
member.summary:
Camera view matrix.
Defines the transformation matrix from world coordinates into location as seen by camera.

remarks.para: Calculated by . Used / read directly by multiple different places. There is method that should be used instead for the debug camera indicator to work properly.
At some point this should be changed to private instead.
For details on how the camera view matrix is defined, see methods documentation
In short, orientation angles , and define the camera orientation based on setting.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.m_dv2RotationStartCoords
member.summary:
Coordinates in _some_ comparable values, defining where the mouse rotation has been reported to have started from.
Updated at method. Used at calculating the difference to current values at method.

remarks.para: Storing start coordinates and taking in current coordinates on rotation is not strictly necessary at current (8.4.x) version. This was originally implemented for some mouse rotation types that would have required original start point and movement, not just the last delta.

That rotation system is not in use, but the coordinate delivery system was retained, as it will likely help us in the future at making snapping / limitation obedience changes, and it might be useful in other ways as well.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.LockPointerDeviceHorizRotationAxis
member.summary:
Locks user pointer device (mouse etc) based rotation to use current camera orientation settings for rotation axis. This affects the way horizontal rotation behaves on certain values.
This has no effect when is .
This method is intended mostly as internal operation of LC. It's run when , or properties are changed, causing horizontal rotation axis to be locked based on the current rotation settings. The method has been left as public for special cases, where users need to make the same operation without modifying the rotation parameters.
member.remarks: Horizontal rotation axis defines the axis around which the camera is rotated on horizontal user input, e.g. mouse based rotation. Calculation and the effects are described separately for different Orientation modes at enumeration values documentation.

member.summary:

Currently used as if the values were radians, but their "angle" meaning has little consequence, and the type of the values can be freely changed without it affecting camera operations, just as long the values change across the input range is linear and matching values are used in

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.SetCamLocation(SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3)
member.summary:
Sets camera location/orientation and target, affecting distance as well.
Sets target location and view distance, and uses to do the rest.
Does not count as user setting the orientation angles, thus method is not called, and rotation up is not affected.

remarks.para: Used at least by the 3D zoom to fit system.
Note that the distance of the camera is clipped to .

member.param: Absolute origo based camera location in world coordinates.
Absolute origo based camera target in world coordinates.

Cameras new up direction, delivered to .
Note that due to definition with of the up parameter is effectively horizontal mouse rotation axis (). For other orientations it's normal camera up direction.
If not set, or zero vector, previous up direction is used.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.SetCamDirection(SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3)
member.summary:
Sets camera view direction/orientation (from camera to target), keeping camera distance from the target and the target in place.
Calculated by setting the orientation angles based on given camera view direction / up vector, as defined by current .
target () and camera distance () are not modified.

remarks.para: Matrix formations are done by method, that uses orientation angles as source. In effect we should get matrix with matching vectors.
Causes a single ChildPropertyChanged call and view matrix recalculation.
Special / invalid inputs are handled by

member.param: View direction of the camera from the camera to the . Prefers normalized vector.

the new UP direction of the camera to use.
Note that due to definition with of the up parameter is effectively horizontal mouse rotation axis (). For other orientations it's normal camera up direction.
If not set, or zero-vector, previous up-direction is used.
member.returns: True if the view matrix rebuild was successful. The view matrix should have been changed even if false is returned, and it should be usable. It just might be defined using a fallback system.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.RebuildViewMatrix
member.summary:
Rebuilds the view () and combination () matrices based on current orientation angles (, and ), interpreting them as defined by
Sets applicable member variables, , , ,

remarks.para: Does not seem to obey the BeginUpdate/EndUpdate system. We should put some "ViewMatrixDirty" flag and regenerate the matrix only when needed.
Uses for actual orientation angle -> vector transformation, and forms the view matrix based on those vectors.

If the view matrix calculation fails - this is known to happen on if view and up directions are parallel - the system falls back to separately defined up direction, and notifies user with a ChartMessage by calling method.
If DEBUG_CAM_LOCATION is defined and in WPF, a camera location/orientation object is updated instead of the actually used view matrix.

member.returns: True if the view matrix rebuild was successful. The view matrix should have been changed even if false is returned, and it should be usable. It just might be defined using a fallback system.

The variable is later reseted to false at successful view matrix calculation at method.

remarks.para: It should be noticed that as different callers have different information at their disposal, we might get here with different kinds of angles or situations / reasons.
Does nothing if is true.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.SetDefaultValues
member.summary:
Set default settings to NonSerialized fields.
Call from constructor / and methds.

remarks.para: Reason for existence of this is that fields with NonSerialized can have default values assigned for them, but those default values are not set on WF deserialization. Thats why the values must be set on code at method.

If the values are defined as default values on declaration, and separately at method, at some point someone will change one or the other, and we'll have a bug that causes the serialized version to function differently.
By setting the values at here on both use-case, we'll always have the same value set.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.RotationX
member.summary:
Part of defining camera orientation and position, by setting its looking direction rotation around X-axis (pitch, elevation) in degrees.
Selected Orientation mode () defines how the value affects camera orientation and position. See enumeration for more information.
and needs to be set as well for defining camera orientation. The rotation values are taken into account on a specific order, NOT on the order they are set.
In some orientation modes setting this value causes user device horizontal rotation axis to be set.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.RotationXMinimum
member.summary:
Minimum allowed value of property.
This can be used to limit camera orientation / location to some specific area.

remarks.para: It should be note that leaving small angle of disallowed area does not work well with user device camera rotations (mouse etc.), as the check is done on frame renderings, and rotation can thus pass over the limit if done quickly enough.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBox
member.summary: On View3D a certain area is selected that axes are shown around. In effect the axes form a cube that the axes are drawn on three edges of. The area is further specified by drawing walls on some of it's faces. The area can also be visualized by drawing a framebox around it. The FrameBox consists of lines drawn along the edges of the cube.

remarks.para: Visibility for the FrameBox can be controlled using the Style property.
To show only the Framebox, set all walls visibility to false.
Unlike most LC objects, this can be shared between different parents.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBox.FrameBoxStyle
member.summary: Style to present the framebox with.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBox.FrameBoxStyle.AllEdges
member.summary: Framebox is shown on all of the edges of the cube.

remarks.para: This is a property, even though the name. The idea is that usually we have had separate internal variable with this kind of name, and SetLineColor() method for internal setting of the value. Now these have been combined to this property, so that we do not need separate setter method.
The actual data is stored in m_iLineColorInt variable.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBox.m_eStyle
member.summary: Internal property holding the style defining how to present the FrameBox. When the value changes, set this. Handles internal setting. Not the DP setting though.

remarks.para: This is a property, even though the name. The idea is that usually we have had separate internal variable with this kind of name, and SetXXX() method for internal setting of the value. Now these have been combined to this property, so that we do not need separate setter method.
Internal value is stored in m_iStyleInt variable.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBox.m_eStyleInt
member.summary: Internal storage of the Style property, set by m_eStyle.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBox.m_eStyleDefault
member.summary: Default value of the style property.

member.summary: Clean up any resources being used.
member.param: true if managed resources should be disposed, otherwise false.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBox.LineColor
member.summary: Color of the FrameBox line color.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBox.Style
member.summary: Style that defines how the FrameBox is presented.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.FrameBoxObject
member.summary: Drawable caching object that holds one framebox object to be drawn on screen.

remarks.para: This is part of a test for implementing shareable object support for LC. This is the actually drawn object, that can't be shared, The FrameBox object is the one that can be shared and that contains the user controllable settings that notifies this one of changed settings and this one checks the FrameBox for settings when generating DD. This also needs the dimension information from the view, and dirtying of the DD based on those changes is done through setDirty() interface.

member.param: Engine to draw the FrameBox with. Does not fully obey the given engine.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.View3D.m_frameBox
member.summary: Property for the UI side Settings object of the FrameBox. On set makes sure that the FrameBoxObject has references to the new settings object. This in turn removes the ref from the old one, marks the DD as dirty and causes new frame to be rendered.

remarks.para: Done like this, as a property, mainly for testing / showing as an option. Usually on LC we have the variable as internal, freely accessible by all, and SetXXXX method for setting the value, that does things that needs to be done when it's set. This one combines those two, and the setter does the things normally done in the SetXXXX method. This way the internal variable is harder (not impossible) to modify without the updates. The actual underlying variable is m_frameBoxInt. ******** NOTE! This makes code reading quite unrelaxed, as any ITEM NAMED LIKE THIS SHOULD NOT BE CONSIDERED TO CAUSE SIDE-EFFECTS ON SETTER! THIS SPECIFIC CASE CAUSES CHART TO BE RERENDERED, WHICH IS NOT EXPECTED FROM SETTING VALUE TO m_* NAMED MEMBERS!! ********
The setter is currently set to private, as currently there should be no need for anybody else to modify the object ref.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.View3DBase.GetZoomEdgeDistances(SharpDX.Vector3[],System.Single[]@)
member.summary:
Helper for solving distances to furthest points that should be visible on 3D zoom to fit operation.
Calculates the max distances of 3D points affecting ZoomToFit in direction of the given vectors. Idea is to give view edge normals, outside the view, and thus solve how much to move the camera in order to get the furthest objects to be included in the view.
member.param:
List of directions to calculate the directions at. Currently vector count must be 4.
For perspective these are the vectors normal to view area edges. For orthographic these are camera vertical & horizontal directions.
Float array of the maximum distances along the normals. If all works, it's 4 items long. On problems the list array is empty.
member.returns:
true if no problems were detected. False if the distance calculation failed somehow.
One known case for false is that there was no points to evaluate. This happens easily if there is nothing visible, or supported, like in volume models.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.View3DBase.ZoomToFitOrthographic
member.summary:
3D ZoomToFit operation for perspective camera.
Assumes that we're doing zoom.
Current version does not support labels / titles etc yet. It handles just the walls / frame-box and data
Handles both and projection types. The calculations are based on and world dimensions are modified through based on the results.

remarks.para: The idea is practically identical to the method and documented there.

Difference is that instead of getting the view area edge vectors and their normals, we can just the view matrix vectors directly, as the view area is defined by infinite rectangle, not as square based pyramid.

Unlike on perspective projection, on orthographic we could use the direct projection and then do the calculations on 2D space. Current implementation however does not do that, as it was assumed that it would be slower and this approach was practically ready.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.View3DBase.ZoomToFitPerspective
member.summary:
3D ZoomToFit operation for perspective camera.
Assumes that we're doing zoom.
Current version does not support labels / titles etc yet. It handles just the walls / frame-box and data

remarks.para:
The idea goes roughly like this.
Get list of 3D points
Get 4 vectors (rays) that define the edges of the view area (square based pyramid)
Form Orthonormal vectors to these vectors
Calculate distance of each point to the edges. In effect distance in direction of each of the normals.
Select largest distances in each direction
Take ZoomPadding into account by increasing the distances enough to provide padding of appropriate size.
Calculate new camera position candidate on vertical and horizontal direction based on that direction FOV, so that the edges of the view area from that position cuts the selected points. In effect, calculate the crossings of the edge vectors if positioned at the selected farthest points.
Select farthest away camera candidate, and move it to match the closer camera. This way the non-definitive camera candidate view direction points are centered.
Set the camera.
Other obvious approach would be to project all points to view plane and calculate the distances and move camera accordingly.
That however does not take into account the distance, and would require us to do recursive calculations until the error would vanish.
Current method does not take the titles / labels etc 2D objects into account on zooming. This could be fixed similarly to the way we handle padding.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.View3DBase.GetMouseRotateFactor
member.summary:
Get effective mouse rotation factor to calculate values to deliver to camera as rotation angles / amounts.
This is affected by the user set rotation sensitivity and view size.
Multiply screen coordinates in pixels by return value of this method to get values to pass on to .
If chart is not set, will fallback to a default constant value.

remarks.para: This method capsules the calculations of how the mouse movement affects camera rotation, taking into account the user settable parameters. If the system needs to be modified, this is the place.

Idea is to multiply screen coordinates by this value and use those values as rotation amounts with cameras rotation methods. Later on the calculations could be done on camera side, if any reason for having actual coordinates there is seen.
Calculation matches that of v8.3, it's just moved here.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.AddInverseChild(Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine)
member.summary: Creates a new inverse child gridline of the given imaginary line. Can not be called for real lines. Uses given lines values for determining the initial angles and points so we do not need to actually calculate them. The given child must have it's values already calculated.

member.returns: Screen coordinates of the intersection of the two circles.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLineTree.m_dLimitFactor
member.summary: Factor of the given limit distance for determining the cutpoint. Cutting distance C is calculated by C = F*S + I, where I is this, S = m_dLimitDistance and F = m_dLimitFactor.

member.summary: Increment to the cutting distance. Cutting distance C is calculated by C = F*S + I, where I is this, S = m_dLimitDistance and F = m_dLimitFactor.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLineTree.DetermiGridLinePoints

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLineTree.NextValueCandidate(System.Double)

member.remarks: Uses m_dRad (radius), m_dLimitDistance, Previous value and last img. line's properties as source data.
member.param: Previously used value. Could be fetched, but little nuisance to set here.

member.summary: Rounds the given value to some nice value based on previous and estimated next value.
member.remarks: Uses previous value, m_dRad (Radius) and m_dLimitDistance fields as input.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewRound.ViewRoundBase.FixZoomRectFromMouseLocations(Arction.Wpf.Charting.RectangleXYF@)
member.summary: Modifies the rect for the use in zooming calculations. Makes proper aspect ratio corrections to a rect, forces it to have positive size, and takes m_bRectangleZoomAboutOrigin into account.

remarks.para: The returned rect's size is always positive in both directions. The start point corner can not be determined from the rect alone. This is due the use of the rect in drawing operations, where the contents get culled otherwise.
The aspect ratio following always modifies the StopX or StopY parameter, not the start point, unless the ZoomCenteredOnOrigin (etc) is enabled.
The input rect's size CAN BE NEGATIVE in either direction.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewRound.ViewRoundBase.FixAspectRatio(Arction.Wpf.Charting.RectangleXYF@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Fixes aspect ratio to match the view aspect ratio. Keeps X,Y coords if Center property is false (default), negative sizes allowed (suggested in some cases). Does not reduce the rect size, only increases it.
member.remarks: Center property can be used to increase the size on both directions.
member.param: If true, keep the rect center in place. Otherwise the X/Y is kept in place (which is not necessarily the left/top)
Increases the size same amount on both directions.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewRound.ViewRoundBase.SetMarginClipping
member.summary:
Enables margin clipping on current device if the margin clipping in general is enabled.
Store the value returned and call the other version of method to return the original value.

remarks.para: This method does NOT keep track of the calls, so using the return rect is not mandatory. There however is no warnings if accounting fails on caller side.
Does nothing if chart or engine is not available.

member.returns:
Original clipping rect. store this and set it back using the other if necessary.
Returns empty rect if margin clipping is not enabled.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer
member.summary: Persistent series rendering layer. Series can be rendered in a bitmap layer and the actual series freed. Saves a lot of memory, CPU and GPU resources, especially when rendering hundreds or thousands of series. The layer itself is rendered in the chart just before line series objects.
member.example: Consider a typical use case of FFT monitoring, where one data line series is collected periodically and added in the layer in full. The layer shows historic information of thousands of FFT strips. By using the persistent series layer, each series has millions of points, and the dozens of new strips can be added every second. By freeing the series itself after rendering it to the layer, the total memory consumption does not rise, and the system won't run out of memory even if the monitoring lasts several weeks.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer.#ctor(Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.ViewXY,Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisX)
member.param: X axis, whose series will be used in this layer

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer.Clear
member.summary: Clears the rendering layer and sets the size to size of the chart control. Sets all data transparent (ARGB=0,255,255,255).

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer.Clear(System.Windows.Media.Color)
member.summary: Clears the rendering layer. Sets all data to given color.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer.RenderSeries(System.Collections.Generic.List{Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.PointLineSeriesBase})
member.summary: Renders list of given series into the layer, in one batch. Faster than calling RenderSeries many times.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer.MultiplyAlpha(System.Double)
member.summary: Allows decaying or bringing the layer more visible.
member.example: MultiplyAlpha(0.8) sets the alpha to 80% of existing alpha (decay). MultiplyAlpha(2) would adjust it to 200% (more visible).

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Diag.Asserts
member.summary:
Internal asserts / debugging features for LightningChart and related components.
Combines the assert actions required on LC to single class, that can be used to stop process / notify user or developer of possible situations that should not have happened.

remarks.h3: Methods are grouped to two different group
remarks.para: Methods named as *Dev are intended for Arction internal operations and ignored when running client compiled code. The methods require ARCTION_DEBUG define to be set.
Methods named without the Dev ending, are "public" method, in a way that they are active in client / released code as well.
The implementation and actions of the methods might change in relation to existence of debugger and DEBUG define (if it's a debug build).
The asserts can be implemented in many ways, that is seen as suitable. The intention is to select best way to notify user / client / dev / Arction of a situation that should not have been possible.
On some cases Assert methods of Debug or Trace namespace is used, but also Debugger.Break and throwing exceptions is a valid method of delivering the information.
As a rule, all the nonDev asserts use the same way, and all to Dev versions use some other.
The method is defined in a shared file, used by different projects, and thus the methods are available across different projects. Some projects might contain specific implementation though.
The class is partial, and as such can be extended locally by content on other files.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Diag.Logger
member.summary:
Static general logging tool.
Writes logs to the file defined in the Path member.
Slow, but easy to use in any static environment as it does not require file initialization.

remarks.para: File to write is defined by Path member.
The file is opened separately on every call to the method, so use of this utility is slow and should be used only in special situations.
It should be noted that all of the users will have one instance (per namespace) and thus all users write to the same file.
Log writing does not cause exceptions. All errors that are encountered are quietly disregarded.

member.param: Message to write to the output file.

member.name: P:Arction.RenderingEngineGDI.RenderingEngineGDI.HeadlessMode
member.summary: Defines if the engine is supposed to work in headless mode. If this is set, the engine does not try to create backbuffers visible to the screen, or update the UI components.
member.remarks:
Note that this does not directly imply or require for the engine to be in service mode, but it is useless to set this to false if in service mode, as that one takes precedence.
GDI engine does not use this information in any way.

member.name: P:Arction.RenderingEngineGDI.RenderingEngineGDI.ServiceMode
member.summary: Property one can use to get information from the engine defining if it's in service mode or not. In service mode the engine refrains from doing certain operations that are not allowed to be done when running as service. The state is automatically detected and can not (normally) be set.
member.remarks:
Note that this information is quite identical to the HeadlessMode, but takes precedence, so that no matter what the headlessmode states, if this is true, the engine is in effect at headless state. On debug interface there is a setter method for this, so that the service mode can be tested.
GDI engine does not use this information in any way.

member.name: P:Arction.RenderingEngineGDI.RenderingEngineGDI.FPS
member.summary: Get FPS. Returns negative value, if not supported. Implements IRenderingEngine.

member.name: P:Arction.RenderingEngineGDI.RenderingEngineGDI.IsQLAASupported
member.summary: Tells if QLAA is supported by engine. Implements IRenderingEngine.
